HEADLINE: Warm Water Killed the Lobsters

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
A''PERFECT STORM'' of sustained high water temperatures, low levels of dissolved oxygen and the toxic impact of ammonia and sulfides created lethal conditions for lobsters in western Long Island Sound in September 1999 and all but certainly explains why they suddenly died in huge numbers, researchers said last week.
 But in a series of reports delivered at a symposium on Monday at Stony Brook University, they sounded less certain about whether and to what degree pesticides contributed and said it was an area that needed more study.
 The 1999 die-off, which lobstermen said occurred with shocking speed between Sept. 19 and 22, abruptly ended a peak period for catches, essentially wiped out the $100 million lobster industry, idled hundreds of New York and Connecticut lobstermen who had been hauling a record 500,000 traps, and sounded alarms as far north as Maine. 
 Shell disease, marked by eroded and discolored shells that make lobsters unmarketable, has also spread in eastern Long Island Sound, where lobsters are less plentiful. But the impact of the 1999 die-off was greatest in western waters of the Sound, where the lobsters and the lobster industry were concentrated. Last year, the lobster catch was less than one-tenth of its peak of 8.2 million pounds in 1997. 
 Participants in the symposium described the die-off as a major environmental event, and in the view of some researchers, it was an ominous if still tentative sign of global warming. Long Island Sound is at the southern edge of the Maine lobster's East Coast range.
 ''Global warming is definitely happening, and it's happening in Long Island Sound,'' said Karen Chytalo, a marine habitat protection official for the State Department of Environmental Conservation. But Jack Mattice, director of the New York Sea Grant program at Stony Brook, was more tentative, saying that anything that raised water temperatures was a threat to lobsters, and ''it could be global warming.''
 Long Island and Connecticut lobstermen who attended the symposium continue to suspect that lobsters were pushed over the edge by mosquito pesticides applied in communities around Long Island Sound to combat West Nile virus, which first appeared in the United States in 1999. Until that year, they said, lobsters had always rebounded once the late-summer conditions of high water temperatures and low dissolved oxygen ended.
 ''I've seen plenty of warm water, but lobsters catch up,'' said Joseph Finke of Bayville, president of the Western Long Island Sound Lobstermen's Association. What had never happened before, he said, was that healthy lobsters gave way to ''nothing but death and destruction'' over just four days. 
 But in reports delivered at the symposium, co-sponsored by the Connecticut and New York Sea Grant programs, researchers said that mosquito pesticides including methoprene, malathion, resmethrin and sumithrin could not account for the catastrophic 1999 die-off, even though the compounds were found to be extremely toxic to lobsters.
 The pesticides, in different combinations and at different times, were in use both before and after the die-off in New York City, on Long Island and in Westchester and Connecticut as government and health officials reacted to the onset of mosquito-borne West Nile virus with emergency ground and aerial spraying. Genetically, lobsters are closely related to mosquitoes. 
 Many lobstermen believe the pivotal event came on Sept. 19, when the remnants of Hurricane Floyd, by then a tropical storm, dumped heavy rain on Long Island and flushed pesticides into the Sound in storm runoff. 
 Gladstone N. Jones III, a lawyer in New Orleans representing more than 100 lobstermen from New York and Connecticut in a federal class-action suit against manufacturers of pesticides used around Long Island Sound in 1999, said there was powerful evidence that pesticides triggered the September 1999 die-off. He described lobsters as ''nothing but big mosquitoes'' that were highly sensitive to mosquito pesticides. 
 Mr. Jones said two pesticide manufacturers named in the suit had agreed to a settlement for an undisclosed amount, but reported in Newsday last Wednesday as $3.75 million. He said that Cheminova, the manufacturer of malathion, had declined to settle. A hearing is scheduled Dec. 10 before Judge Thomas C. Platt in Federal District Court in Central Islip.
 ''The lobstermen are absolutely certain about what happened in September 1999,'' Mr. Jones said. ''It happened when Hurricane Floyd came through around Sept. 19, and suddenly hundreds of thousands of lobsters were pulled up dead in their traps. And this industry never recovered. It is essentially over.''
 But the researchers said that even assuming all the pesticides applied in counties around Long Island Sound at the time of the die-off had been washed into the water, the amounts were too small to kill lobsters or to weaken them enough that they would succumb to already hostile water conditions.
 Though Sea Grant officials billed the findings as definitive, they stopped short of exonerating the pesticides and said more research was needed. They also acknowledged that pesticide concentrations in Long Island Sound in the crucial September 1999 time frame were difficult to gauge. 
 ''It's really hard to go back and take measurements five years later,'' said Sylvain DeGuise, a researcher from the University of Connecticut who has studied the impact of pesticides on lobsters.
 Researchers were emphatic, however, in depicting what they concluded were the principal causes of the 1999 die-off. They also described the die-off as a more gradual event, foreshadowed in 1997 and 1998 when smaller die-offs were already signaling trouble ahead.
 By the time of the September 1999 die-off, they said, lobsters had already been exposed for more than two months to water temperatures above 68 degrees, considered the upper limit they can endure. As they withdrew from shallower, warmer waters to the cooler bottom waters, they were also subjected to low oxygen levels, or hypoxia. 
 Researchers said that by late summer the lobsters, in moving away from hypoxic areas, crowded more closely together, only to be overtaken by hypoxia again. Hypoxia occurs as water grows warmer, and when algae and other marine organisms die, sink to the bottom, and consume oxygen on the bottom, already low in oxygen, as they decompose.
 Conditions grew even more hostile because there was too little oxygen for aerobic bacteria to continue this decomposition, leaving the job to anaerobic bacteria -- or bacteria that don't use oxygen -- which release ammonia and sulfides toxic to lobsters.
 The researchers said winds from a storm on Aug. 30 thoroughly mixed waters of Long Island Sound that had stratified during a dry summer, with warmer water near the surface.
 Carmela Cuomo, a marine ecologist and geologist at the University of New Haven, said the mixing brought fresh oxygen to the depths but also raised bottom water temperature by 1.5 to 2 degrees in just six hours, pushing it into the red zone for already weakened lobsters.
 Robert Wilson, an associate professor of marine sciences at Stony Brook University, said the increase in oxygen, in combination with high temperatures in the bottom waters, could also have contributed to a rise in toxicity linked to releases from heavy metals in the sediments.
 A tiny parasite, the paramoeba, which spread through the packed-together lobsters, emerged in the research as an opportunistic organism that overcame already weakened lobsters, but not as a cause of the die-off. 
 Dr. Cuomo contended that even without the mixing event, the lobsters' long exposure to high water temperatures, low dissolved oxygen, ammonia and sulfides were enough to account for the 1999 die-off. She also warned that those conditions in Long Island Sound were far from rare. ''The probability of it happening again is very high,'' she said. 
 She said periods of hypoxia, which generally occur in later summer and early fall and are most severe in western Long Island Sound, were now a persistent annual feature. ''It's year after year after year, and it's getting longer,'' she said. 
 In one of several pointed exchanges between lobstermen and researchers at the symposium, Matthew De Maula, a lobsterman from Mattituck, questioned why only healthy lobsters, some from Maine, were used by researchers, when the effects of pesticides might be clearer in tests using Long Island Sound lobsters weakened by high temperatures and low oxygen. ''Why would you start with healthy animals?'' he asked.
 Dr. Cuomo replied that lobsters placed in waters simulating conditions on the bottom of Long Island Sound in 1999 would be dead before testing could begin.
 The future for the industry looks bleak. A graph of lobster larvae showed an up-and-down pattern leading to 2002, when levels fell to historic lows and stayed there. Penelope Howell-Heller, a senior fisheries biologist at the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection, said it was the first time in 22 years of records that larvae levels had stayed so low for three consecutive years. Research also showed female lobsters were at low levels.
 The low numbers of larvae raised concerns about the use of mosquito pesticides on land because of the extraordinarily lethal effect even tiny amounts could have on the larvae and also on juvenile lobsters.
 Researchers reported that as little at 33 parts per billion of the pesticide malathion in Sound water would kill 50 percent of adult lobsters, with juveniles and larvae deemed even more susceptible. Malathion was used in New York City in August and September 1999. Suffolk sprayed malathion by air over parts of Huntington in late September 1999. Resmethrin, applied by truck in Nassau and Suffolk in the fall of 1999, was found to be nearly as toxic.
 Dr. Michael N. Horst of the Mercer University School of Medicine in Macon, Ga., said in a telephone interview that although methoprene was also toxic in low concentrations to lobster larvae and had been part of what he described as ''a cocktail of pesticides'' applied in New York City in 1999, amounts had apparently been too small to contribute to the lobster die-off.
 But he said the toxicity of the compound raised alarm. ''You would have to be an absolute fool to use methoprene near coastal waters,'' he said. Suffolk County uses methoprene annually as part of a mosquito control program targeting mosquito breeding areas, many of them in coastal wetlands. 
 The Sea Grant programs in New York and Connecticut, the co-sponsors of the symposium, are part of a national Sea Grant network of 30 university programs under the auspices of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The Sea Grant programs perform coastal research and seek to educate the public about coastal issues.
 In 2001 Congress allocated $6.6 million to N.O.A.A. to research the causes and economic impact of the 1999 lobster die-off and shell disease in Long Island Sound. Connecticut contributed an additional $1 million. The National Marine Fisheries Service and environmental agencies in both states participated.
 The relatively modest amount of money available for research left many questions unanswered and confined researchers to addressing relatively narrow issues. The researchers agreed that more research, data and monitoring were necessary, including research into the role of mosquito pesticides in weakening or killing lobsters. 
 The lobster die-off followed the collapse of the clamming industry in South Shore bays in the 1970's, an event variously attributed to overfishing and pollution, and the decimation of scallops in the Peconic bays beginning in 1985, when the brown tide algae bloomed profusely and sickened the shellfish. The algal blooms, which have occurred periodically since 1985 in the Peconic and South Shore bays, are still a puzzle to researchers.

HEADLINE: Powering Up

 BODY:
The Long Island Power Authority wants to put a pair of windmills on the site of the abandoned Shoreham nuclear plant.
 Oh, boy: Two little windmills, each able to light up about two dozen homes, spinning in the breeze off Long Island Sound, near what was supposed to have been a mighty 800-megawatt nuclear plant powering Nassau and Suffolk into a blazing, electrified future. (If you didn't live on Long Island back then, an explanation: Shoreham was built but never used, largely because of safety concerns. What's left is a $6 billion sinkhole that Long Islanders are still slowly filling, one jacked-up utility bill at a time.) 
 Windmills rising in the Shoreham ruins sounds like a fable, a scene from one of those end-of-the-world Kevin Costner movies, but we did not make it up. We like it, though, because it tells you all you need to know about the perverse state of affairs afflicting Long Island and its power supply.
 Because there is no Shoreham, we on Long Island don't have to worry the way Westchester does about meltdowns and terrorism at the Indian Point nuclear plant on the Hudson. But we don't have reliable, abundant power, either, and we live in continual fear of brownouts whenever the weather gets hot. Our utility rates are among the highest in the country, and the cost of electricity keeps rising -- three rate increases in 2004 alone. And yet we remain insatiable consumers of energy, and our efforts at developing renewable energy sources remain drawing-board abstractions or inconsequential curiosities -- like the Shoreham windmills.
 LIPA recently unveiled ambitious plans to attack the problem on the supply side. It announced that it would replace a defunct power cable between Connecticut and Northport, which could nearly double the flow of power. It has contracted to bring in a 660-megawatt undersea cable from New Jersey -- an ''extension cord'' plugging the island into the mid-Atlantic power grid, whose energy will most likely be cheaper. The authority is also planning to erect a wind farm -- enormous turbines off the South Shore that might be a headache for fishermen and birds, but a blessing to the rest of us.
 Increasing the area's power supply and making it more reliable are essential, for obvious economic reasons. Our frayed, aging grid is a burden on everybody. But amid all the talk of powering up, a few things have been conspicuously missing from the discussion: serious efforts to support clean, renewable energy, and government leadership to promote the simplest, cheapest and most effective tactic of all, conservation.
 We are heartened by New York State's recent announcement of an ambitious clean-energy plan, which would require that 24 percent of the state's electricity come from renewable resources by 2013. This goal, which puts New York in the same league as farsighted (that is, smog-choked) states like California, is not as far off as you might think, thanks to existing hydroelectric turbines at Niagara Falls.
 But Long Island has no hydroelectric options, nor any other significant supply of renewable energy. And like everywhere else, the dominant cultural imperative here is to consume, not conserve; thermostat-watching and sweater-wearing went out with Jimmy Carter and never came back. Now we hop in the S.U.V. to Best Buy to get a home theater system for the McMansion, guiltless in our gluttony.
 What we do have, though, is lots of sunshine, the wind and sea, and 2.8 million residents who might be more open to reining in their energy appetites, if only the people in charge would make it an urgent priority. Windmills -- even little ones -- are a promising start. It's too bad the start has been so long in coming.

HEADLINE: Creating an Oasis in an Old Mill Town

BYLINE: By C.J. HUGHES

 BODY:
THE older residents of Seymour, Conn., tend to think back on Aug. 19, 1955, as ''Black Friday.'' On that day, the twisting Naugatuck River hopped its banks, slicing a watery path of destruction from the town of Torrington, up north, to Derby, at the river's mouth.
 In Seymour, the rushing river killed two people and destroyed dozens of homes, a bridge and the town library, leaving a gaping hole behind and damaging the city's economy -- already stung by postwar factory closings -- so badly that it would take decades to recover.
 That moment might finally have arrived.
 Buildings that survived the flood have become the centerpieces of a thoughtful renewal project that has turned rundown warehouses and dusty shops into antique stores and art galleries that weekend visitors are slowly discovering. 
 Simultaneously, home buyers who work in Fairfield County but cannot afford to buy there are finding that Seymour, in nearby New Haven County, has similar-sized homes -- running the gamut from Revolutionary War Colonials to 1990's neo-colonials -- that can cost a third less than those along the Gold Coast of Long Island Sound.
 And despite a surge of housing development in the last few years, some of which has touched off fiery local zoning battles, pockets of the hilly comma-shaped city still cling to their rural charm.
 ''Seymour has always been a popular place to move to,'' said Ruth H. Murphy, an independent agent who has sold homes in the city since 1970. ''But we're getting much too busy now. There are so few starter homes left.''
 Home prices have jumped by 40 percent in the last three years, Ms. Murphy said. That means that for $175,000, the low end of the market, a buyer can get a ranch-style home with four bedrooms and one bathroom, on less than a quarter of an acre. On the higher end, a new colonial with four bedrooms and two and a half baths is on the market for $699,900, and a house in the Country Club Estates subdivision is listed for $430,000, doubling in price since it was built 12 years ago.
 Another sign of Seymour's growing popularity: an elevated part of Route 8, which threads through the city, is seeing rush-hour traffic jams for the first time that have the intensity of those on Interstate 95. 
 Still, these hassles can seem negligible after frustrating searches in other parts of the state. After she accepted a new job in Fairfield, Sevi Regis began looking at real estate near her native Westport. She wanted an older home, but she didn't want to take on a mortgage, which limited her options. 
 Ms. Regis discovered Seymour through an Internet search. On the day she visited, she settled on the third home she saw, a two-story colonial-style house on a quarter-acre near Route 67, for $275,000. A 20-minute commute to work and a gym down the road clinched the deal. 
 Plus, she felt downtown Seymour had potential.
 ''They have a good plan to develop it in a quaint and charming way,'' Ms. Regis said.
 That charm in large part comes from red-brick sidewalks flanked by old-fashioned gaslight-style lamps. Park benches shaded by locust trees provide plenty of spots to contemplate Queen Anne, Art Deco and Federal architecture. Much of the city's fresh face is the result of a $400,000 investment from the state in a mid-1990's beautification project.
 Now, a small independently owned movie theater, the Strand -- where $3 buys a ticket to recently released films -- sits at one end of Main Street, while a Beaux-Arts columned post office anchors the other, across from a Metro-North Railroad station that offers six weekday trains to New York City. 
 But it is Bank Street that epitomizes the city's new look, especially in the Seymour Antiques Company, a four-building, 20,000-square-foot pistachio-and-grapefruit-colored confection where 80 dealers sell pieces like Depression-era China cabinets and mid-1800's step-down dressers.
 Joseph Migani, an architect who is often credited as the pioneer of Seymour's rehabilitation, bought the building, a boarded-up former furniture company, for $100,000 in 1995, and moved his architectural firm to offices on the third floor this fall. 
 Other merchants -- a publishing company, art gallery, antiques wholesaler -- soon followed or are about to. Yet Mr. Migani said Seymour needs more upscale food and drink options, and plans on opening a cappuccino cafe in his complex sometime next year. He also wants to install a restaurant in an 1870 post-and-beam structure, attached to a 1917 building, that he recently bought across the street. Two stores and 12 artist studios are also being considered for that pair of buildings.
 ''In 10 years, Seymour will be an oasis in a very, very bland suburbia,'' Mr. Migani said. ''But we're more than hopeful about the recovery here, because we've bet the farm on it.''
 With 1,000 acres of protected public land, Seymour hasn't fully capitalized on its most historic natural asset, the Naugatuck River, which, despite roaring over a rock ledge in the middle of town, is largely hidden from view.
 Some residents want to change that, however, by building a running-and-biking path that will eventually stretch along the river from Derby to Beacon Falls. The Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection has also committed money to build a bypass channel so fish, and kayakers, can skirt a river dam.
 Yet forces for recreation and conservation often clash with town leaders who have a record of approving large subdivisions while resisting efforts to increase the mandatory size of the lots. 
 The most recent dust-up occurred over Seymour's approval of a plan to build 68 homes on part of a 167-acre parcel, with 54 more homes to possibly follow, in the Skokorat section, near the Bethany border. 
 But development does not always mean progress, said Brian Barrett, a fourth-generation Seymour resident and treasurer of the Seymour Land Conservation Trust, a group that has purchased 121 acres of undeveloped land in the town. He said Seymour's ''quality of life is being compromised because of this development.''
 The developer, David Mack, president of David A. Mack Properties of Southport, Conn., said the company has been sensitive about making sure the heavily wooded site maintains its natural beauty. ''The property will be less than 50 percent developed, so there will be lots of open space,'' he said, adding that he could have put in hundreds of condos but thought the market would prefer single-family homes. 
 Sprawling subdivisions are less evident in the older neighborhood around Church and West Streets, where slope-roofed Colonials, often the homes of former mill owners, perch over steep, twisting roads. These homes rarely come up for sale, brokers say, though inquiries about them catch longtime residents by surprise.
 ''When we tell them what their homes are worth, they are like, 'Whoa,''' said Rosalie Averill, a Seymour native and an agent for Rupwani Associates Real Estate. ''It's hard for them to grasp how much their homes have appreciated.''
 Gazing down on the valley, Seymour seems to have made out better than neighboring Ansonia and Derby, where hulks of empty factories are a common sight. 
 In Seymour, the New Haven Copper Company, which has been in the city under different names for 155 years, and the Kerite Company, a 150-year-old manufacturer of cables, are still in operation. 
 Today, Seymour has three elementary schools, a middle school and a high school, which is adding a new science wing that will open for the 2005 school year. The high school posted SAT scores in 2004 of 502 in the verbal part of the test and 497 in the math, compared with the state average of 515 on each part of the test.
 The influx of newcomers and the growing art scene does prompt some worries about higher rents, brokers said, particularly from older residents who live or work downtown. Yet others are taking the city's transformation in stride. Jimmie Principi, the owner of Jimmie's Place, a 47-year-old restaurant in town, said: ''Sundays used to be quiet and now there are people on the streets. Besides, manufacturing isn't what it used to be anyway.''
 But in a nod to an earlier era in a fast-changing town, a sign over the door at Jimmie's says, ''Sports shirts and slacks required after 6 p.m.''

HEADLINE: It's Hard to Be Neutral Nowadays

BYLINE: By J. ALEX TARQUINIO

 BODY:
IN a perfect world, mutual funds would make money no matter which way the markets moved. A small group of funds aims to do that in the real world. Of course, there are catches: the funds don't always reach that goal, analysts say that many charge excessive fees, and the only fund in this group that Morningstar Inc. recommends buying is closed to new investment. 
 Most of the funds in the group either have the words ''market neutral'' or ''long short'' in their names. But beware: not every mutual fund labeled long-short aims to be market neutral, said Dan McNeela, a fund analyst at Morningstar. Some long-short funds operate more like hedge funds, trying to bolster returns with aggressive tactics. 
 Ideally, Mr. McNeela said, managers of market-neutral funds should divide portfolios equally between long and short positions. ''Then they're not hoping for a general increase in the stock market, so they can focus on stock picking,'' he said.
 Mr. McNeela said that three long-short funds from Laudus Rosenberg have generally kept to the market-neutral path since the late 1990's. Although all three are divided equally between long and short positions, they have subtle variations, said Stephen Dean, director of global products strategy at AXA Rosenberg, based in Orinda, Calif., which manages the Laudus Rosenberg funds.
 The Laudus Rosenberg Value Long/Short Equity fund holds more value than growth stocks and short-sells more growth than value stocks, he said. Although performance should not correlate with the overall stock market, the managers are betting that value stocks will do better than growth stocks. ''You've got to make bets, otherwise you get no returns,'' Mr. Dean said.
 And while Laudus Rosenberg Large-Midcap Long/Short Equity invests in larger stocks, the value fund concentrates on smaller companies. ''The small-cap sector offers more opportunities for stock pickers, because it's less efficient,'' Mr. Dean said.
 Each of these funds make up a third of the Laudus Rosenberg Global Long/Short Equity fund, with the remaining third invested in European stocks.
 In 2002, when the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 23.4 percent, the value fund returned 27.9 percent. But all three funds lost money in 2003, with total returns ranging from negative 3.8 percent to negative 7.2 percent, while the S.&P. 500 rose 26.4 percent. Through the first three quarters of this year, the value fund returned 3.4 percent; the large-midcap fund, 1.7 percent; and the global fund, 0.3 percent.
 Mr. Dean said that market-neutral funds could diversify investors' portfolios but that ''people have to be willing to accept lower returns when the market is up strongly.'' The idea behind owning a market-neutral fund, he said, is to smooth out returns in a portfolio over time by making money in down years.
 In theory, Mr. McNeela said, market-neutral funds could be an option for investors who worry that stocks have become too expensive. But he said that most of these funds charge too much. 
 The published annual expenses for all three Laudus funds hover around 3 percent. Mr. Dean said that this was partly because of accounting rules. The funds pay dividends on the stocks they short and receive dividends on those they hold. The dividends they pay are listed with expenses, while the dividends they receive are added to the yield.
 ''In fact, those dividends we pay would be largely offset by dividends paid to us on the long side,'' he said. If the costs of dividends were not included, total expenses for the value fund would drop to 2.05 percent from 3.06 percent, he said.
 But Mr. McNeela said that total annual expenses higher than 1.5 percent ''become questionable.'' The one fund that he does recommend, Calamos Market Neutral, has total annual expenses of 1.51 percent. But this fund has been closed since March.
 Calamos pursues the market-neutral strategy a bit differently, using convertible securities to hedge the risk of a broad market decline. Convertibles generally pay dividends and may be exchanged for another asset, typically shares of common stock. The Calamos strategy worked better than a long-short strategy during the stock market bubble, Mr. McNeela said. ''In 1999, long-short fund managers often shorted stocks that they thought looked expensive,'' he said, ''but then those stocks became even more expensive.''
 The Calamos fund had total returns of 13.7 percent in 1999 and 10.3 percent in 2000. By comparison, Laudus Rosenberg Value Long/Short Equity had negative returns both years, losing 11.7 percent in 1999 and 3.9 percent in 2000. In the first three quarters this year, the Calamos fund returned 1.4 percent.
 ALTHOUGH the fund's use of convertibles should reduce any correlation with the equity markets, the fund may not be immune to a downturn in the bond markets because the fund holds lower-quality debt, in the BBB to BB range, said Nick Calamos, a co-manager of the market-neutral fund for Calamos Investments, in Naperville, Ill.
 ''If there's a shock to the bond markets, and there's a huge flight to higher-quality bonds, then that would hit the fund,'' he said. ''But if we have gradually rising rates, because the Fed is taking the training wheels off of the economy, that could be a really good environment for this fund.''
 The fund will probably reopen once the convertible market becomes more robust, Mr. Calamos said, but right now there is a high demand for convertibles and not enough being issued.
 Although the fund's annual returns have been consistent in all types of markets, investors' perceptions of it vary, Mr. Calamos said. ''During the bull market, nobody had much interest in this fund,'' he said, ''and during the bear market, everybody loved this fund, so we had to close it.''

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 3; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2605 words

HEADLINE: Who Is Richard J. Codey Anyway?

BYLINE: By JOSH BENSON

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
RICHARD J. CODEY, New Jersey's next governor, was irked.
 ''You made some remark to one of the women on my staff that I'm an unlikely reformer,'' Mr. Codey, in his usual calm manner, told an interviewer recently. ''Now, she thinks you're a jerk. And she's right.''
 When it comes to Mr. Codey -- the 57-year-old Senate president and the state's longest-serving legislator -- what you see is not always what you get. 
 In a state infamous for politics that is at once two-fisted and palms up, Mr. Codey -- after more than three decades in the state Assembly and the Senate -- is a deal-maker who gets along well with his colleagues. Even as he has caromed from West Orange to Trenton to Princeton and points in between since Governor McGreevey's stunning decision to step down almost two months ago, Mr. Codey has remained in character: he has kept a low public profile, preferring back-room negotiations to mission statements or grand gestures. 
 But there are also times, as several prominent Democratic power brokers have found out when they opposed him, that Mr. Codey can be less than collegial -- like when he bristled at the suggestion that his longtime insider status made him an unlikely figure to overhaul the way New Jersey's government does business once he assumes the governor's office on Nov. 16. 
 Pointing out the numerous battles he has had with party officials in Essex County and around the state who ''have been after him for a decade,'' Mr. Codey asserted his political independence. 
 ''I'm not going to sit hear and picture myself as some great reformer,'' he said, ''but I think people would certainly say: 'Wait a minute. This is a guy with the guts to buck the party, and the bosses are against him.'''
 ''You'll see, as time goes by,'' he promised, ''I'll take a lot of people by surprise.''
 It is only logical that Mr. Codey, an easygoing family man who is unknown to most voters, should want to establish his credentials as an agent of reform. After all, as he begins his 14-month term -- a term that depending on his decision will either be the pinnacle of a lengthy public career or the prelude to a re-election bid next year -- Mr. Codey will find himself at the head of a party, and a state government, that has been tarnished by scandal. He will also have the unenviable task of overhauling the state's finances, since he will be inheriting from Mr. McGreevey a projected $3 billion shortfall in the next budget year.
 What this means, in all likelihood, is that Mr. Codey's time in office -- and his political future -- will be a test of whether he can bring about fundamental alterations to the very system that created him, from reining in campaign contributions to eliminating dual office holding.
 ''I think that sort of agenda of reform will be a crucial measure of his leadership,'' said David Rebovich, managing director of the Rider University Institute for New Jersey Politics. ''I think if Codey succeeds, he will not only be viewed as a reformer, but in some ways the savior of the Democrats and their social and economic agenda.''
 That Mr. Codey should even have a chance to be a Democratic messiah is something of an accident. Mr. Codey, who is about to assume one of the most powerful and high-profile governorships in the nation, hardly looks the part. With the substantial build of a long-retired shooting guard, Mr. Codey looks slightly uncomfortable in a suit. He wears a large Seton Hall commemorative basketball ring on his right hand. And when he talks, he does not so much project as mutter. He comes across, in short, like a man who is far more likely to be interested in box scores than poll numbers. 
 Mr. Codey said he was as stunned as everyone else when Mr. McGreevey announced in August that he was stepping down after having a relationship with a man whom he made his homeland security adviser, and that it took him a while to digest the notion of assuming the governorship for more than a year. 
 Then, as he was reeling from the news, a controversy erupted when several powerful Democrats tried to block Mr. Codey's ascension by having Senator Jon S. Corzine seek the office in a special election. But Governor McGreevey's intransigence and Mr. Corzine's unwillingness to sow discord within the party assured that Mr. Codey would indeed straddle the offices of governor and Senate president.
 But first he has to get there, and it seems Mr. Codey's takeover will not be entirely without controversy. In a final dramatic flourish, Mr. McGreevey has insisted on remaining governor through the final minutes of Nov. 15, a development that took Mr. Codey and other legislators aback. As Leonard Lance, the Republican minority leader, said dryly, ''If the governor's time frame now is between the 14th, 15th and 16th, that's a decision I will leave to him.''

No Mansion for This Governor
 Even now, with the title acting governor firmly in his future, Mr. Codey says he intends to spend as much time as possible with his wife and two sons -- and with the fifth-grade basketball team he coaches and whose practices are already written into his gubernatorial schedule. Nor does Mr. Codey plan on going anywhere near Drumthwacket, the governor's mansion in Princeton, which, he noted with admirable candor, smells. 
 ''Where I come from,'' he said, repeating his what has become a stock one-liner these days, ''we were always trying to get out of public housing, not into it.''
 However anxious Mr. Codey is to establish some sense of routine, he will not have much of a grace period in office. In addition to satisfying a clamor for governmental reform following the federal investigations and indictments of former McGreevey aides and fund-raisers, Mr. Codey will have to plunge into what will probably be an extremely unpleasant business of slashing spending or generating new revenue to avert what is shaping up to be a potential budget mess. 
 At the same time, Mr. Codey will be under instant pressure to make some sort of announcement about his political future. With Mr. Corzine eagerly waiting in the wings, other Democrats weighing their options and several Republicans already in campaign mode, speculation about Mr. Codey's plans on running for a full term in 2005 have already begun. ''The decision is clearly going to have to be in the next few months,'' he said. ''I understand and appreciate that in politics, the next election starts the day after the last one. And in this case, we might have people announcing before I even take office.''
 Conventional wisdom says the Democratic nomination would be Mr. Corzine's for the asking, with widespread party support and virtually limitless financial resources. But with Mr. Corzine's aversion to intraparty fighting, it is far from clear that he will willingly enter into a potentially divisive primary. On the other hand, Mr. Codey has a history as an effective infighter, having beaten back challenges over Senate leadership positions by two powerful Democrats, George Norcross of Camden and the former senator John Lynch of Middlesex, and come out on top of an ugly internecine struggle in his home county of Essex. 
 Mr. Codey's contentious history with the state's power brokers goes back to 1993, when he was assistant minority leader of the Senate. At the time, Mr. Norcross and Mr. Lynch pushed to weaken Mr. Codey's position, eventually installing two other senators to the same rank. He clashed again with county leaders in 1997 over legislative leadership posts, and once again in 2001 after the election of Mr. McGreevey.
 The pattern continued this year when Mr. Norcross and Mr. Lynch teamed up with Representative Robert Menendez of Hudson County to try to force a special election that would effectively have blocked Mr. Codey from succeeding the governor. And once again, Mr. Codey survived. ''It didn't work,'' he said, allowing a smile.
 Mr. Codey has also been at odds with his local county organization, running and winning on two occasions in opposition to the party-endorsed slate of candidates.
 Still, Mr. Codey said that he did not expect those past clashes to carry over into his governorship, if only because of the impracticality of it for everyone involved. 

No Date, 'but You Can Talk'
 ''I think they understand that it's in their interest, for those 14 months, for it to succeed to a certain extent,'' he said. ''It doesn't mean you have to date, but you can talk.''
 In typically pragmatic fashion, Mr. Codey said that he regarded the unusual influence of some of the power brokers as a fact of life. ''I didn't create that, and I'm not going to change it,'' he said. ''It is what it is.'' 
 For now, Mr. Codey is saying little, except that he is keeping his options open. 
 ''I'm not obliged to do anything,'' he said. ''My decision is not going to be political, but based on what's right for the people in terms of what they've been through and what's right for my family.''
 As for what Mr. Codey will actually do when he gets into office, for now he is playing much of that close to his chest as well, or, as he put it, ''I'm not going to be tied down to any goals.'' 
 What is clear is that Mr. Codey fully intends to take advantage of whatever time he has in the state's most powerful position. Even in the absence of a detailed plan of attack, there are already some broad indications of what the Codey agenda might look like.
 His attitude toward governmental reforms, at least so far, can best be described as purposeful but measured: he favors the finance reforms already mandated in Mr. McGreevey's executive order -- prohibiting the awarding of most state contracts to businesses that have contributed to state or county political committees or gubernatorial candidates -- and will encourage the Legislature to codify those rules into law. And he said he would like to impose limits on how much money people can contribute to county committees each year.
 Moreover, Mr. Codey wants to establish an independent auditor general capable of investigating sitting administrations, and says that he has already ''made it clear'' to Attorney General Peter Harvey that ''there isn't a corruption office unit working it the way they should be.''
 ''It has to be a priority,'' he insisted.
 Although he intends to maintain his Senate title while he is governor, Mr. Codey insisted that he would like to phase out such dual office-holding. And although he is unenthusiastic about the notion of establishing an elected lieutenant governor -- there are already more than a dozen such proposals before the Legislature -- he says he will seek to change the rules of gubernatorial succession in other ways. In addition, he says his goal ''in the next decade'' is the public financing of state elections. 
 ''We in New Jersey, I think, have a good system whereby we have only the statewide office elected,'' said Mr. Codey, referring to the governorship. ''I like our system.'' 
 They are hardly the words of a fiery reformer, but in terms of actual ability to rewrite New Jersey's rules of government, that might turn out to be a very good thing. On one hand, Mr. Codey's affinity for working within the system has never made much of an impression on New Jersey voters; a majority, according to a recent Fairleigh Dickinson University poll, still say they have never heard of him. But on the other hand, Mr. Codey has accumulated enormous influence among the lawmakers whose help he will need in passing laws during his abbreviated term in office.
 If the specifics of what Mr. Codey hopes to accomplish are not yet clear, his legislative colleagues seem to think that he is in a strong position to push for anything he wants.

'A Wholesome Lyndon Johnson'
 ''I think that Dick has an incredible amount of potential to get things done because of his understanding of Trenton and ability to work with people,'' said William Gormley, a veteran Republican senator from Atlantic County. ''You almost could say he's like a wholesome Lyndon Johnson -- you don't have the mean-spiritedness of L.B.J. but you have the ability to bring people together, the respect of members of both parties and an open door to everybody. And because he dealt with it for so many years, he understands the problems we have in our districts.'' 
 Mr. Gormley also said an important asset for Mr. Codey would be the fact that he came to office without an election. ''I think because he hasn't been lying around for eight or nine years, making promises to get the job, he has some unique advantages,'' he said. 
 But another well-known Republican senator, Thomas H. Kean Jr., whose district embraces parts of Essex, Morris, Somerset and Union Counties, suggested that Mr. Codey's greatest difficulty, especially on the reformist parts of his agenda, was likely to be in persuading recalcitrant Democrats to go along with him. 
 ''The real test for Codey will be to determine how effectually he can force the members of the Democratic leadership in the Assembly to recognize that comprehensive reform is needed,'' Mr. Kean said. ''That's the fight that's going to emerge.''
 But Mr. Kean, who is himself weighing a run for governor on a platform of governmental reform, agreed that Mr. Codey was sufficiently adept to do the necessary maneuvering. 
 ''Clearly, Dick's been a competent Senate president, and I think he'll be able to transfer his 31 years of experience in the Legislature to the larger leadership responsibilities of being governor. A lot of people like Senator Codey, even when they don't agree with 100 percent of his agenda.'' 
 Improving the state's mental health care system will clearly be a priority for Mr. Codey, whose wife, Mary Jo, has fought through both breast cancer and mental illness. (Mr. Codey famously conducted his own undercover investigation in 1987 of hiring practices at a state psychiatric hospital, the results of which led directly to reforms.) Among his proposals as governor, Mr. Codey said, would be to provide tuition relief to college graduates who went to work in state psychiatric hospitals.
 ''We want to change the way we treat them, to come up with a game plan for the next century on how we deal with mentally ill patients,'' he said.
 Mr. Codey also wants to go beyond Mr. McGreevey in an area that the departing governor has emphasized in the closing days of his term: public financing of stem cell research. 

Stem Cell Bill 'Was All Mine'
 ''That stem cell bill,'' he said, referring to Mr. McGreevey's commitment to finance a stem-cell research institute, ''that was all mine. My idea. Now I want to continue to make New Jersey one of the leaders in the country in that research.'' 
 Mr. Codey also wants to improve on the environmental record established by the McGreevey administration by amending a measure that he co-sponsored this summer easing restrictions on development of wide swaths of New Jersey's open land, known derisively as the ''fast-track bill.'' 
 ''When you do a major piece of legislation like that quickly, you're bound to make some mistakes,'' he said. 
 And while he is still adjusting to the trappings of his changed status -- he asked sarcastically at one point whether an award he was to receive from a medical college later that day had anything to do with his new title -- Mr. Codey had a ready assessment of the sort of effect he expected to have on state government. ''I'm not telling you I'm going to be able to go into Trenton and reform everything that's wrong,'' he said. ''Nobody can, and that includes me. But you'll see some things that no one's ever done before, I think, that will show that the corruption and waste and fraud is not going to be tolerated any more.''

Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk; RESTAURANTS; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 1135 words

HEADLINE: Rat Pack Chic

BYLINE: By DAVID CORCORAN

DATELINE: MONTCLAIR 

 BODY:
SITTING in the office of his title search company, overlooking the decaying eyesore that was a half-abandoned century-old paper factory, Richie Cecere allowed himself a daydream. It was a snowy morning about nine years ago, and on that weed-choked triangular lot opposite the Walnut Street train station he imagined something so retro, so early-60's swanky, so utterly un-Montclair that even in hindsight it seems outlandish.
 The dream went this way: He would transform the blighted factory into a Manhattan-style supper club from the era of the Rainbow Room and the Copacabana, the kind of place he loved to visit as a wide-eyed teenager fresh off the train from Jersey. It would have everything: mohair banquettes, mahogany and black leather, glistening tableware, visiting celebrities, chorus girls -- and, of course, a band. Richie Cecere's Jazz Orchestra! Eighteen guys on a banked and spotlighted stage, belting out the brassy, expansive arrangements that laid down carpets of sound for the likes of Frank Sinatra and Dean Martin and . . . ladies and gentlemen . . . the legendary . . . Mis-ter Bobby Darin! 
 For Mr. Cecere (pronounced seh-SEER-ee), now 58 and still an enthusiastic pop singer and occasional drummer, the fantasy was not out of reach. All it took was money, sweat equity and perseverance. 
 He preserved the old building but more than quintupled its floor space, to 14,000 square feet from 2,500. The turret that rises from the onetime factory like a 19th-century clock tower? It wasn't there before. Mr. Cecere added it, to accommodate an elevator. That 10,000-bottle wine cellar? Push a hidden handle and you enter the ''secret room,'' a 25-seat dining room meant for private parties and favored by notables like Eddie Murphy and Danny Aiello.
 The results of this one-man urban-renewal project are (to select just the right early-60's adjective) fabulous. Where Cecere's still needs work is in the kitchen.
 Not that the cooking -- the work of Frank D'Amico, formerly of Brunello in Wayne -- is bad. It consists of high-quality ingredients, turned out with competence if not much imagination. But it is expensive, and it is uneven. On each of two evenings, our table of four dropped well over $300 without breathing hard. At these prices, inconsistency is an affront.
 Dinner starts out promisingly, with a basket of wonderfully fresh and crusty peasant bread from the nearby bakery Gina's Panificio, accompanied by black and green olives, a little foil round of soft Bel Paese cheese and a rousing tapenade of olives, anchovies and capers. The wine list, too, is Italian-accented and well chosen, with many luxury bottles but a reasonable selection at the lower end and by the glass. The genial, tuxedoed staff is good at making recommendations.
 But appetizers -- many of them $17 or more, the price of an entree at many fine establishments in this very town -- are all over the place. Buffalo mozzarella has the yielding texture and creamy, nutty taste of homemade. Why, then, was it paired with slices of tasteless tomato? (The tomato was better on a second visit, but this time it was yellow tomatoes in a portobello mushroom appetizer that lacked flavor.) A panful of scungilli needed better adornment than an unappetizing overdose of oil.
 Three other seafood starters did justify the price tag. ''Richie's Famous Steamed Littleneck Clams,'' a dozen of them, deserve their fame; they were tender and filled with flavor, enhanced by butter and garlic and broth. Six Fisher Island oysters were fresh, sweet and well handled. And four enormous butterflied Maya prawns had a splendid grilled taste that did nothing to block their own considerable flavor.
 Main courses were solid and well presented but otherwise unmemorable, with several exceptions. Dover sole was not boned tableside, or even thoroughly boned, but as a piece of fish it was admirable -- big, tender, mild and perfectly cooked. Pistachio-crusted rack of lamb hit the center of its $42 target. Juicy seared scallops had a surprising accompaniment of avocado-tomato salsa that neatly complemented a thick, sweet pomegranate reduction.
 On the other side of the ledger, full-flavored osso buco was undercut by a salty, canned-tasting sauce. And while chicken Don Ameche was accurately labeled ''very, very spicy,'' nothing prepared me for the innocent-looking red vegetable hidden its brown sauce. As I bit into the thing, I realized, too late, that I was ingesting a habanero pepper. Then my life passed in front of my eyes, and everything went blank -- especially the taste of the overly dry chicken.
 Desserts, by the talented Marisol Ruiz, included a superb orange panna cotta, at once creamy, soothing and beautiful to look at. Strawberry shortcake incorporated excellent berries, almond shortbread and a sauce unexpectedly enlivened by basil. Cappuccino creme brulee was far better than average, and white-chocolate cheesecake on a shortbread crust got the cheesecake job done. 
 Never did a restaurant, even Wolfgang Puck's or Daniel Boulud's, better deserve to be named for one person. Richie Cecere's, which opened in June 2002, is eminently worth a reservation and a self-guided tour. The jazz orchestra, which is every bit as swinging and smooth as Mr. Cecere hoped it would be, plays in the upper-level dining room on Fridays and Saturdays, starting at 8:45 p.m. It and the chorus girls, who are to start this weekend, will make an impression unlike any to be found in this restaurant-crazed town. Now they need a band in the kitchen that plays as flawlessly as they do.

Richie Cecere's
2 Erie Street, Montclair
(973)746-7811
www.richiececere.com

GOOD

ATMOSPHERE -- Great, if expensive, fun. An old paper mill remade into a stylish supper club, with dining on three levels and a jazz orchestra channeling Frank Sinatra on weekends.
SERVICE -- Friendly, professional and polished.
SMOKING -- Allowed on the main floor and a second-floor lounge. Other areas are nonsmoking.
WINE LIST -- Long and pricey, but with a decent selection in the $30's and $40's; wines by the glass ($8 and $10) are well chosen.
RECOMMENDED DISHES -- Grilled Maya prawns, buffalo mozzarella, oysters, steamed clams; Dover sole, pan-seared scallops, rack of lamb; panna cotta, strawberry shortcake, sorbets, creme brulee.
PRICE RANGE -- Appetizers: $8 to $18; entrees: $25 to $55; desserts: $8 to $14.
HOURS -- Open daily. Dinner: Monday through Saturday, 5 to 11 p.m.; Sunday, 5 to 10 p.m. Bar stays open until 2 a.m. Live music starts at 8:45 p.m. on Friday and Saturday.
CREDIT CARDS -- American Express, MasterCard, Visa.
RESERVATIONS -- Necessary on Friday and Saturday.
WHEELCHAIR ACCESS -- Fully accessible, with an elevator to the restrooms.
IF YOU GO -- The restaurant is just north of downtown Montclair, opposite N.J. Transit's Walnut Street Station.

HEADLINE: The County Formerly Known as Squaresville

BYLINE: By ALEX WILLIAMS

DATELINE: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif. 

 BODY:
THE new MTV show ''Laguna Beach: The Real Orange County'' was a ratings hit with the youth of Laguna Beach when it had its debut two weeks ago, which shouldn't come as a surprise. When a global television network trundles into a bohemian seaside hideaway and attempts to recast it as the American Monaco, that will get the attention of the local kids. 
 Not that the kids didn't have some quibbles.
 ''We're not that rich,'' said Bradley Burdick, 18, who was working the register at Laguna Surf and Sport, the shop where Stephen, the heartthrob, works on the show, a serial following a real-life clique of in-crowd teenagers through five months of parties, cellphone calls, hookups and more parties. 
 ''Everyone from here agrees that that show was just embarrassing,'' added Alex Richey, 22, who was seated nearby; she found the idea that the students would throw a formal ''Black and White'' party at a rented hotel suite laughable -- unless MTV was paying. 
 ''What they show about Laguna, it's like all about materialism,'' complained Ben Tomkinson, 18, who grew up with a few of the cast members. ''Laguna's actually a really artsy, rootsy place.'' 
 But such are the realities in the new, rebranded Orange County. Particularly since ''The O.C.'' a Fox drama, became a pop-culture phenomenon last year, the formerly quiet patchwork of planned communities and insular beach towns south of Los Angeles has become recognized worldwide, however improbably, as the embodiment of all things hip, youthful and glamorous.
 To those of us with roots in Orange County, that is bizarre. It is as if the organizers of New York Fashion Week had pulled up stakes in Bryant Park and relocated their tents to Bergen County, N.J., the newly discovered capital of cool. A little background: Twenty years ago, after decades in Northern California, my parents moved to a recently constructed beige tract house like many, many, many others in Mission Viejo, a town then run by a subsidiary of Philip Morris. 
 In one early conversation with a native, I mentioned Tom Waits. ''Weights?'' she responded perkily. ''My husband and I want to start lifting weights.''
 That, to me, was Orange County. 
 Before I left for good in 1989, I had come to the conclusion that hip culture had made only one great foray into the home county of the Western White House of Richard M. Nixon, and that was in 1970 when bands of Yippies invaded Disneyland and planted a Vietcong flag over Tom Sawyer Island.
 Could it have changed so much? 
 To find out -- as well as to understand the appeal of a mythic Orange County that has suddenly captured the youth-culture imagination -- I ventured back behind the Orange Curtain recently. The locals, I found, are well aware of their new place in the spotlight, and they are not always happy about measuring up to a pop stereotype. 
 Brandon Matteson, 19, who grew up in Irvine, just inland from ''The O.C.'' terrain, complained that at a snowboarding camp he attended at Mount Hood, in Oregon, ''my nickname instantly became 'O.C.' for the entire 15 days I was there.'' 
 He rolled his eyes. No one seemed to recall hearing anybody in Orange County calling it ''the O.C.'' before the Fox show. ''It's so obscene how people think if you're born here, you're automatically issued your Land Rover and your $1 million house on the beach,'' he added. 
 T. Jefferson Parker, author of a number of crime novels set in and around Laguna Beach, most recently ''California Girl,'' said: ''It's wonderful escapism. On 'The O.C.' everyone is bronze and uniform and the beaches are lovely. That plays into everyone's desire for some kind of Shangri-La.''
 The current fascination with Orange County taps the need Americans seem to have to create a bubble in which playful adolescent fantasies can act themselves out in the sun, removed from any real-world complications like war, unemployment or split ends. There are other beach meccas, sure, but Miami, with its cocaine subculture and salsa beat, is just too complicated, and someplace like East Hampton, with its fortress-like hedgerows, too impenetrable. 
 Orange County, by contrast, has always wanted to present to the world a Clearasil-clean face of prosperity and order. It is an update, essentially, on the suburban optimism the Beach Boys conjured 40 years ago. (Nowadays, the kids have fun, fun, fun until Daddy takes the charge cards away.)
 Jon Wiener, a writer for The Nation and a history professor at the University of California, Irvine, believes this region's flawless new television image echoes cultural impulses akin to the county's historic political conservatism. ''It's an attempt to hold onto that California of the 50's and 60's, that paradise for middle-class white people,'' Mr. Wiener said. ''The sun, the beach, the healthiness, the happiness of being young. I see this as a nostalgia for the California of yesteryear.''
 Although the main casts of ''The O.C.'' and ''Laguna Beach: The Real Orange County'' are completely white, during the week I visited, The Los Angeles Times reported that for the first time whites were no longer a majority of the county's nearly 3 million residents. Long a renowned bastion of conservative Republicans, the county's politics are beginning to reflect an influx of Asian and Latino immigrants. 
 Traditionally, the northern border served as a green line with Los Angeles, a place viewed as a grimy inner city by many Orange County residents, experts said, especially those who fled formerly white neighborhoods like Compton a generation ago.
 ''Your typical Orange Countian believes he or she deserves a little slice of perfection,'' Mr. Parker said. ''Nobody wants to drive into the mob of L.A.''
 Ever since Disneyland opened in Orange County in 1955, developers there have tried to conjure residential variations on ''the happiest place on earth.'' ''It's such a bubble -- that's what everyone refers to it as,'' said Meghan Flaherty, 25, a hairstylist who grew up in Irvine, a city sprung from a single master plan.
 Cocooned, homogeneous communities develop cultural codes all their own, which in turn can be distilled into stereotypes quite useful to Hollywood. 
 By the time the first episode of ''Laguna Beach'' was shown on Sept. 28, we already knew that Lo would shop for her M.A.C. cosmetics at South Coast Plaza megamall, the same mall where Marissa infamously shoplifted during ''The O.C.'s'' first season. We already felt we recognized Morgan with her mirror-shiny brunette locks and her affluent, sun-kissed vocal inflections. Doesn't she call to mind a straight-arrow real-life variant on ''The O.C.'s'' Summer?
 MTV is straightforward about what drew it to Laguna Beach, a community just a few miles south of Newport Beach, the setting for ''The O.C.'' (which is actually shot in Los Angeles County). ''The idea that was around here was, 'The O.C.' is so popular with our viewers, but it's a scripted show -- how cool would it be to show the real kids down there?'' said Tony DiSanto, an executive producer of ''Laguna Beach.'' He declined to speculate about any larger meaning the county may embody. 
 The relentless Southern California cliches of ''The O.C.'' set have even turned them into cues for a drinking game by local young people at weekly ''O.C.'' parties. 
 ''Every time Marissa gives some lame dumbfounded look, you have to drink,'' explained Marc Conner, 26, of Huntington Beach. ''Every time Ryan gives the glare, you have to drink.'' And every time someone disses the 909 area code, for humbler Riverside County nearby -- bottoms up.
 A bubble can be a protective shell. Or it can be a trap to those who find it stifling. ''Pretty much everyone I knew talked about wanting to get out as soon as they turned 18,'' said Colin Dunleavy, 22, who helped finance his own escape from Mission Viejo's uniformity by selling his high school yearbook for $75 to another student who forgot to order one. He made it as far as the Underdog Records shop in Laguna Beach, where he now works.
 To anyone who does know ''the real Orange County,'' it is surprising to hear Laguna Beach described as such by MTV. The town, long a liberal bastion hidden away in a G.O.P. Valhalla, has a thriving gay population, and it is still the best place south of Venice Beach where one might search for a shop selling hemp-flour pasta. Culturally it has more in common with Provincetown, Mass., than Garden Grove, the Orange County home of the Crystal Cathedral, with its ''in-car worship'' lot outside. 
 But Laguna is changing. According to a recent report by the California Association of Realtors, the town, with a median home price of nearly $1.4 million, is now the third most expensive address in California, ahead of even Newport Beach, John Wayne's old hometown, Kobe Bryant's new one. 
 ''There's a generation of people who went to that area to enjoy a beachy lifestyle that had the place sold out from under them,'' said Kem Nunn, the author of the surfing novel ''Tapping the Source,'' who lives in south Laguna Beach.
 The same sort of conspicuous consumption seen in Laguna Beach as well as ''Laguna Beach'' is becoming commonplace, as Orange County develops a more worldly culture, befitting its world-class economy. 
 At the LAB Anti-Mall in Costa Mesa, a plus-chic shopping center, one can find a Comme des Garcons top or a pair of custom Nikes fashioned like punk brothel creepers -- a rare outpost of the sort of shopping experiences available on Melrose Avenue in Los Angeles or SoHo in New York. 
 Shaheen Sadeghi, a former fashion designer who once ran Quiksilver Inc. sportswear and who developed the LAB, said urban tastes are creeping in. ''Half the people don't know anything about what's going on, half the people are rocking and rolling through it,'' he said.
 If anything, I was surprised by how much rocking and rolling was going on in Orange County. In the years since I left, a small but assertive counterculture has taken hold, largely in inland towns where the ''O.C.'' types would only tend to land if they took a wrong exit off the 5 Freeway. Artists' lofts and galleries are cropping up in downtown Santa Ana. There is a bit of a coffee-house culture in Costa Mesa, virtually in the shadows of the South Coast Plaza.
 There is now the alternative OC Weekly, which is perhaps even sassier than its parent publication, The Village Voice, from which it was spun off in 1995.
 ''I'm going to show you the real Orange County,'' promised Rebecca Schoenkopf, who writes the salty ''Commie Girl'' nightlife column for The OC Weekly. If that paper functions as something of an id for Orange County, Ms. Schoenkopf, clad in knee-deep red plastic boots and a black micro-mini the width of a weightlifter's belt, is the id's id.
 Over the course of an evening, she led a tour of the barfly underbelly of inland Orange County, populated by skate rats and slumming hipsters. If Seth from ''The O.C.'' had wandered in, any of them would have been happy to grind the Lacoste crocodile on his shirt under the heel of a boot. It was all very ''core,'' to use the word favored in such circles -- that is, deeply authentic.
 We ended up at a gritty Santa Ana bar called the Fling Cocktail Lounge, which was populated equally by tattooed skinheads and Sunbelt rummies with silver pompadours and Marlboro-tinged facial creases. Onstage Eddie Chiaverini, a beloved local lounge singer who performs under the name Eddie Day (imagine if ''fat'' Elvis had packed on a few extra peanut butter and fried banana sandwiches every day) belted out a karaoke version of a song by an Orange County thrash band, Lit. Tattooed hipsters mouthed the lyrics almost solemnly, as if singing their own anthem. 
 That's the energy that has fueled an Orange County alternative rock scene for years, from bands like the Adolescents and Offspring. 
 On Fox and MTV, Orange County may be reaching the apotheosis of its stereotypical image of affluent white privilege, at the very moment that that reality is being blown away. 
 ''They need to do a real reality show on Orange County,'' said Nativo Vigil Lopez, president of the Mexican-American Political Association, in Los Angeles. ''It's surreality that they're presenting to the viewing public. Just take a look at the census.'' 
 Mike Davis, the author of ''City of Quartz'' about Los Angeles and a history professor at the University of California, Irvine, said, ''Orange County demographically is changing very, very fast, and this 'spoiled rich white kids in the sun' stuff is very much a bunkered way of life.'' 
 ''It's like watching Pompeii living at the end of its days,'' he added.
 If any rival producers from CBS or HBO are listening, here's one idea for a ''real Orange County'' show for next fall:
 ''What I want to see is the sitcom about the Latino family that moves into a Vietnamese neighborhood,'' said William Fulton, a senior scholar policy planning and development at the University of Southern California. ''When you see that, you'll know that the perception of Orange County has finally caught up to reality.''

HEADLINE: The Leading Candidates in a Crowded Pop Field

BYLINE: By Jon Pareles

 BODY:
THE furiously contested 2004 election has had an unexpected artistic bonus: more political songs than any election since the dawn of rock 'n' roll, and more openly partisan songs than anyone might expect. In the protest-song heyday of the 1960's, songwriters devoted themselves to denouncing specific injustices and vaguely yearning for peace. This year, folkies and punks, rappers and indie rockers are taking sides and dusting off their rebel credentials by bluntly savaging the Bush administration. The pop polls are completely one-sided: although there were both pro-war and antiwar songs around the Iraq invasion, not one high-profile song currently supports the president. The music may make a political difference -- the six Vote for Change tours that converge for a concert in Washington on Monday are betting that it will -- or it may simply vent or preach to the converted. But rage and frustration are always fine catalysts for music, and at a time when self-absorption rules both rock and hip-hop, politics can provide a wider perspective, one that might even last beyond the current election. No matter who wins in November, here are 10 statements worth a listen.

John Fogerty
 No political songwriter can ignore the 1960's, and the title song of John Fogerty's new album, ''Deja Vu (All Over Again)'' (Geffen), reflects an unhappy nostalgia. The lyrics, more resigned than angry, compare the war in Iraq to the Vietnam War: ''One by one I see the old ghosts stirring/Stumblin' cross Big Muddy.'' Meanwhile, the music makes its own parallel with the Vietnam era, reaching back to a song Mr. Fogerty sang with Creedence Clearwater Revival, ''Who'll Stop the Rain,'' to sound even more plaintive and sadly cyclical.

Babyface
 The sound of the big 1980's benefit single, with stars gathering to share cameos on an uplifting song, re-emerges on the remake of ''Wake Up Everybody,'' produced by Kenneth Edmonds, better known as Babyface; the video is at www.mjblige.com and elsewhere. Mary J. Blige, Ashanti, Faith Evans, Jadakiss, Fabolous and Wyclef Jean, among others, gather to sing and rap on a 1970's-vintage socially conscious soul song about ''hatred, war and poverty'' that was originally recorded by Harold Melvin and the Blue Notes. It's the title track on an album to benefit the Democratic voter-registration group America Coming Together. Amid the old-style invocations of a better world, Missy Elliott's rap cuts through to call for partisan action: ''Listen to me like you listen to 'Fahrenheit 9/11,''' she raps. ''You better go and vote and get up off your back.''

Zack de la Rocha
 ''We Want It All,'' a new song on ''Songs and Artists That Inspired 'Fahrenheit 9/11''' (Epic), is produced by Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails, and it's brilliantly relentless: a nonstop beat and layers of frenzied, droning guitars as Zack de la Rocha shouts, ''Silence is security/and war is peace.'' It's not a coherent argument or a manifesto; it's just a blast of concentrated fury.

Bad Religion
 Punk met politics a generation ago, but it has mostly been an on-and-off relationship; the election year has pushed them back together. Greg Graffin and his fellow punk die-hards in Bad Religion have always used buzz-saw chords to carry not just slogans but also critiques. ''Let Them Eat War,'' from the band's new album, ''The Empire Strikes First'' (Epitaph), goes barreling along as it insists the war is a diversion from economic failures, polishing its punk fervor with bursts of vocal harmony. But it stumbles on didactic lines like ''All he ever gave them was a war and a foreign enemy to deplore.''

Dan Bern
 Yes, there are still topical songwriters working coffeehouses, but they try to stay hard-nosed and witty. Dan Bern learned his verbal free association and his nasal vocal projection from early Bob Dylan, and his election-season EP, ''My Country II'' (Messenger), is unabashed agitprop with some twists. It seesaws between the earnestness of ''The Torn Flag'' and ''Bush Must Be Defeated'' (which is an exercise in rhyming as well as partisanship) and the funnier, but equally pointed, ''Tyranny'' and ''President,'' a countryish bounce in which Mr. Bern places himself in the Oval Office, offers statehood to Cuba, legalizes every kind of marriage and withdraws troops from ''Afghanistan, Iraq, Iran/More trouble than they're worth.'' He adds that he's not running for a second term because ''I hate politics!''

Keb' Mo'
 In theory, protest songs hope to make themselves obsolete. In practice, they can be recycled all too often. A National Lampoon parody once advertised a nostalgia collection called ''Golden Protest,'' and the track lineup of Keb' Mo's album ''Peace: Back by Popular Demand'' (Columbia) probably isn't too different. It reaches back to the 1960's and 1970's to remake ''The Times They Are A-Changin','' ''For What It's Worth,'' ''Imagine'' and another version of ''Wake Up Everybody.'' Keb' Mo' treats the songs as soulful, cozy melodies rather than calls to action, and his one new song, ''Talk,'' is strangely undemanding: ''Hello, Mr. President,'' he sings, ''let's talk to each other, that's all.''

Lamb of God
 Metal bands savor the prospect of apocalypse, and life during wartime lets them trade fantasy for reality. In ''Now You've Got Something to Die For,'' from Lamb of God's new album, ''Ashes of the Wake'' (Epic), the band directly addresses the war in Iraq. With crisp and unstoppable thrash momentum, the beat gallops and sputters as Randy Blythe howls about ''Flags for coffins on the screen, oil for the machine/Army of liberation, gunpoint indoctrination.'' Changing riffs as if shifting gears on a Humvee, the music sounds both dire and exhilarating as the song warns, ''We'll never get out of this hole until we've dug our own grave/And drug the rest down with us.''

Colonel Claypool's Bucket of Bernie Brains
 Lyrics tend to be afterthoughts for jam bands, and funk bass riffs are clearly the top priority for Les Claypool's latest jam-band supergroup, which includes Buckethead on guitar and P-Funk's Bernie Worrell on keyboards. But instead of the usual jam-band escapism or philosophical musings, he vents his political disgust on the album ''The Big Eyeball in the Sky'' (Prawn Song). Mr. Claypool cackles his way through songs like ''Junior'' (''Uncle Sam got a master plan like Vietnam'') and ''Ignorance Is Bliss'' (''The market's on the boil/We're down a couple quarts of oil/The President is reacting/Like an old near-sighted mohel''). This time, there's bitterness between the punch lines.

Sum 41
 Until now, Sum 41 has devoted most of its churned-up punk and metal songs to private adolescent identity crises. But in a moment of election-year seriousness, its new album, ''Chuck'' (Island), has a cover full of combat imagery, and the first single, ''We're All to Blame,'' worries that we'll ''supersize our tragedies bought in the land of the free,'' then lavishes a power-ballad chorus on an indictment of American greed: ''Everyone wants it all with no sacrifice.''

The Bots
 ''Fuzzy Math,'' a video and free MP3 download at www.thebots.net, is as cheap as a cheap shot gets. It chops up bits of the president's speeches to have him say things like ''The best way to win an election is deliberate deception.'' The Bots can't transform prose into rapping, but they pace phony sound bites with a snappy electro track that punctuates pronouncements with ratchety percussion and synthetic horns. It's negative campaigning with all its snide panache.
