SECTION: Section 3; Column 2; SundayBusiness; MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; Pg. 25

LENGTH: 1388 words

HEADLINE: Squeezing More Pennies From a Cache of Cash

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
YOU'VE been letting your cash reserves pile up but are frustrated by the almost insultingly skimpy returns -- in many cases, well under 1 percent -- that they are producing. A fine reward, you may be thinking, for your thrift when so many feckless Americans are in debt.
 But try to look at the bright side. The Federal Reserve has embarked on a path to raise short-term interest rates, which had sunk to their lowest levels in 45 years. Its latest move came on Sept. 21, when it raised the target for its overnight benchmark to 1.75 percent from 1.50 percent. 
 Yet savers do not have to rely solely on the government to get more for their money, whether it be a stash for emergencies, sidelined stock-market money, an uninvested windfall or just an ordinary household account. There are many things you can do to enhance returns, with little or no additional risk. 
 Money market mutual funds, where nearly $2 trillion of this money already resides, will pay higher rates, of course, as the Fed tightens credit. Despite the usual lag as their portfolios mature and are replaced with higher-yielding securities, most money market funds in mid-August regained the rate advantage they have traditionally held over money-market deposit accounts at banks. At the end of the third quarter, the funds' rates averaged 1.09 percent for the latest 12 months, versus 0.92 percent for the banks' money market accounts. 
 By year-end, according to Peter Crane, a vice president of iMoneyNet in Westborough, Mass., money fund rates should be pushing 1.5 percent. Still, that would be only a little more than half of the consumer inflation rate.
 Because interest rates are so low, it is especially important to keep money fund fees to a minimum. ''Strategy No.1 is to move to a low-expense money market fund,'' said Bruce J. Berno, an independent financial planner in Cincinnati. 
 He pointed to the Vanguard Prime Money Market fund, which costs 0.32 percent a year, less than the industry average of 0.56 percent. The fund had a yield of 1.41 percent at the end of the third quarter, above the industry average. 
 Fees can be especially important at a time when some funds charge almost as much or more in expenses than they are providing in yield. At the end of the third quarter, AllianceBernstein Capital Reserves was charging 0.97 percent in annual fees, and its yield was 0.66 percent. 
 And if you have multiple accounts, it is probably a good idea to consolidate them to get the higher rates that larger balances often command. 
 Investors may also get some help on expenses from the Securities and Exchange Commission. Some S.E.C. officials have expressed worries that some money market fees are excessive. 
 Experts also recommend another look at money you may have parked in brokerage house money funds that are typically used as repositories for periodic sweeps of dividends and other account income. Many brokers have set up banks for this purpose, but whether or not such banks are used, the funds' yields are often substantially less than those of ordinary money market funds. 
 If you keep a lot of money in a brokerage-house fund, it never hurts to ask for a bit more yield, or, if you're depositing fresh cash, to ask that it start earning interest faster. It is not unusual for a fund to make you wait five business days before it starts to credit interest, but an investor with a substantial or active account may be able to win a reduction to, say, three days. 
 Alternatively, consider tax-exempt money funds. Because tax-free rates did not decline as much as others during the interest-rate swoon, returns on these funds are currently nearly as high -- and in a few cases, higher -- than those for taxable funds. Tax-exempt funds for your own state, offering an additional exemption, can be even more appealing. 
 Then there is a highly attractive investment that offers substantially more yield but is widely misunderstood or overlooked, partly because of terminology. This is the category of stable value funds, which are sometimes known as guaranteed interest income funds, as capital preservation funds or even as fixed-income funds. 
 Stable value funds, devised primarily for employer-sponsored 401(k) retirement accounts, have portfolios of high-quality, short-maturity bonds ''wrapped'' with insurance contracts that protect against swings in interest rates. Some $350 billion is already invested in them, but many plan participants who have this option may not know it because of the funds' varying names.
 With returns averaging more than 4 percent -- and with risk that is only slightly higher than for money funds -- stable value funds ''have been the life raft for retirement savers through the rocky times of the last four years,'' said Gina Mitchell, president of the Stable Value Investment Association, a trade group in Washington.
 Because of that record, specialists advise workers to look closely at their 401(k) plans and to take advantage of any stable value option. 
 ''We strongly recommend stable value funds,'' agreed Mr. Berno, adding that this was a particularly good time to switch assets into them from longer-term bond funds, which lose substantially more value than short-dated investments as interest rates march higher.
 Reflecting this strong appeal, eight stable value mutual funds have sprung up outside 401(k) plans and have accumulated some $6.6 billion through individual retirement accounts. But their future is clouded by questions the S.E.C. has raised about the proper valuation of the insurance wrap in funds that are not part of 401(k)'s. 
 One stable value fund, the $60 million Principal Investors Capital Preservation, was converted to a money market fund on July 29, and some other sponsors have converted their stable value funds to bond funds. ''They're potentially taking away a great investment for individuals'' outside 401(k) plans, a high-yielding, secure and diversifying instrument for which there is no good substitute, Ms. Mitchell contended.
 Another way to juice up returns on cash reserves is through ultrashort bond funds. The bonds in their portfolios come due very soon -- typically in one to three years -- which means that your capital can then be reinvested at new, perhaps higher rates.
 Judith Lau, a principal at LauOlmstead, a financial planner in Wilmington, Del., said that her firm was putting clients into such funds. ''We find we can do this with only a small differential in the risk level,'' she said.
 She pointed to Schwab YieldPlus-Select, which has an expense ratio of 0.41 percent and an average maturity of 2.7 years. At the end of the third quarter, it yielded 2.6 percent, according to Morningstar Inc.
 Fluctuations in net asset value have been 5 cents or less for the past two or three years, noted Jacob Weaver, a LauOlmstead investment manager. ''We like the stability,'' he said.
 But be aware that some bond funds, though not Schwab YieldPlus-Select, levy redemption fees to discourage short-term trading. That could disrupt portfolio management, specialists warned. 
 Other alternatives include depositing money in credit unions or Internet banks, which may pay higher rates than brick-and-mortar banks. Funds investing in variable-rate loans and even a tax-deferred fixed annuity may also be appropriate, they said.
 AND if you like the higher returns of longer-term bank certificates of deposit, but don't want to give up much liquidity, you can gradually build a ''ladder'' of C.D.'s -- arranging for them to come due in regular progression, then reinvesting them for the same long terms. The ladder, for example, might have 10 five-year C.D.'s, maturing six months apart. Some five-year C.D.'s now pay more than 4 percent a year. 
 To make C.D.'s more attractive, banks have been introducing varieties that give investors at least some of the benefit of rising rates. Called bump-up, step-up, opt-up or index-linked C.D.'s, they allow an investor, in effect, to refinance for a higher yield at least once before the maturity date. But Mr. Crane cautioned that a C.D. paying 2.5 percent ''may look attractive now, but six months from now money funds might be outyielding it.'' 
 Whatever you do, make sure that it fits your circumstances. ''If you want to pay college tuition next January,'' Mr. Berno said, ''you don't want to buy a 12-month C.D.''

HEADLINE: Rumsfeld Rallies Allies; In Surprise, Stops in Iraq

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: ABOARD THE U.S.S. JOHN F. KENNEDY, in the Persian Gulf, Oct. 9 

 BODY:
With support for operations in Iraq flagging in some allied nations, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld gathered 18 defense ministers aboard this symbol of American military might on Saturday to discuss strategy and stiffen any wavering resolve back home. 
 [Mr. Rumsfeld later arrived at an air base in Iraq's western desert on Sunday in a visit that had not been announced beforehand, Reuters reported. He landed at Al Asad air base near Haditha, 125 miles northwest of Baghdad, aboard a C-17 transport plane from Bahrain to meet top Marine commanders and address about 1,500 marines.] 
 Warplanes from the carrier's air wing have been flying about 20 combat missions a day over Iraq and have played a pivotal role in airstrikes in insurgent-controlled Falluja last month that killed an important member of a terrorist network led by the Jordanian-born militant Abu Musab al-Zarqawi. 
 The unusual meeting at sea on Saturday, Mr. Rumsfeld's first stop on a six-day visit to the Middle East and a NATO meeting, assembled defense ministers largely from new NATO members and former Soviet republics, as well as from Iraq, Qatar and Bahrain. The countries have contributed troops, bases and other support to the allied campaigns in Afghanistan and Iraq. 
 In the carrier's cramped, windowless war room, the ministers heard Gen. George W. Casey Jr., the top American commander in Iraq, describe by teleconference from Baghdad the military's plan to defeat an increasingly violent insurgency, to train and equip fully as many as 145,000 Iraqi security forces in time for national elections in January and to start hundreds of new reconstruction and economic projects. 
 In the wake of offensives in Tal Afar, Samarra and northern Babil Province, General Casey said that a majority of Iraq's security problems were concentrated in 4 of Iraq's 18 provinces, including Baghdad and Anbar, to the west. But many of the country's population centers are in those restive areas, scaring off international aid organizations. 
 ''The goal was to mobilize us and show public opinion that we really and truly are together on this,'' Defense Minister Jerzy Szmajdzinski of Poland, which has 2,500 troops in southern Iraq, said in an interview. Public opinion in Poland has been running hard against the Iraq operation, with some leaders there suggesting that Poland should withdraw its forces by the end of 2005. 
 The Iraqi defense minister, Hazim al-Shalaan, dismissed reports that Iraq was descending into a new spiral of violence. ''Samarra is a sign of things to come, and Falluja will soon be next,'' he said in an interview. 
 For Mr. Rumsfeld, a former naval aviator, the four-and-a-half-hour meeting on the carrier allowed him to show off American military prowess as an example to ministers from fledgling NATO countries, prospective alliance members and other nations that the Bush administration has recruited in its efforts in Iraq and Afghanistan. 
 With elections being held in Afghanistan on Saturday, Mr. Rumsfeld exhorted his colleagues to hold fast in that country in a message that could well have applied to Iraq. ''There are always naysayers and doomsayers, and people who are faint-hearted,'' he said. ''But the people who have been determined and steadfast have been proved correct.'' 
 Mr. Rumsfeld often says that more than 30 countries have contributed to operations in Iraq, but the United States has 138,000 of the roughly 160,000 troops there, and has borne a vast majority of the costs. 
 The carrier's air wing is flying 60 missions a day, including flights to Iraq, 250 miles to the northwest, and about 30 others in support of countersmuggling and antiterrorism operations in the Persian Gulf. Capt. Mark Guadagnini, the commander of the 70 aircraft aboard the Kennedy, said, ''We're trying not to bomb unless it's absolutely required.'' He said that a roaring flyby might deter insurgents on the ground. ''We're doing absolutely everything we can to prevent civilian casualties.'' 
 In most cases, the jets fly to an assigned sector in Iraq, and stand ready to help ground troops that come under fire or bomb targets revealed by fresh intelligence. 
 That is what happened on the night of Sept. 26, when intelligence showed suspicious tractor-trailers unloading weapons into buildings in Falluja. Three Navy attack planes, including Lt. Comdr. Ted Heflin's F-14, rolled in on the targets, dropping 1,000-pound laser-guided bombs. ''We took out two buildings,'' he said. American officials said they learned later that the strike killed Abu Ahmed Tabouki, a Saudi believed to be Mr. Zarqawi's right-hand man in Falluja.

HEADLINE: Erase Debt Now. (Lose Your House Later.)

BYLINE: By MICHAEL MOSS

DATELINE: DES MOINES 

 BODY:
MICHAEL A. KNOX thought he had run out of ways to pay off his credit card bills when he got the salesman's call two years ago. To wipe out his nearly $20,000 debt, he was told, all he had to do was take out a new, bigger mortgage on his house.
 Mr. Knox, then 60 and on disability, signed up. The mortgage broker sent him eight checks already made out to his creditors, and Mr. Knox dashed to the post office the day they arrived to mail them.
 But the bigger house payment devoured 75 percent of his income. He quickly fell behind. And the full meaning of what he had done suddenly became clear. 
 By using his mortgage to pay off his credit card debt, Mr. Knox had avoided the humiliation of filing for bankruptcy. But he had put at risk something much more important to him than his pride. In late January, with Mr. Knox in arrears, the Wall Street firm that had bought his mortgage informed him that it was taking away his home.
 ''They're going to have to carry me out of here,'' he told a lawyer in early March. Days later, Mr. Knox, who had suffered for years from depression, was found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning in his sealed-up car.
 Encouraged by low interest rates and rising home values, millions of Americans have been using their homes to pay off credit card bills. One-fourth of homeowners who refinanced their mortgages took out larger loans on their homes in order to pay off credit cards and other debts, according to a recent study by the Federal Reserve. 
 The maneuver is known as debt consolidation, and mortgage lenders are using national campaigns -- from prime-time advertising to e-mail spam -- to pitch it as a sound way to ease the sting of credit card debt, which averages $13,000 for people who don't pay off their balance each month, according to CardWeb.com. For many, probably a vast majority, it has been a boon. Experts say the device is a factor in a recent leveling off of credit card debt and a drop this year in personal bankruptcies.
 But each year, tens of thousands of people -- not just the poor -- lose their homes after trying to cope with their debts this way, industry figures show, and their heart-rending tales are raising alarm among consumer advocates, federal regulators and some mortgage lending officials.
 In Bluefield, W.Va., a retired coal miner, William Anderson, 80, and his wife, Kathleen, 79, owned their home of 45 years free and clear, but lost it in March after falling behind on a new $48,000 mortgage that they were persuaded to get in order to pay off their automobile loans.
 Robert and Shirley McCall of Paris, Ill., were trying to pay off $7,720 in medical bills when they took out a new $22,000 mortgage on their house, but in failing to keep up with the larger mortgage payments, they were warned by their lender in August that they were nearing foreclosure.
 In Macon, Ga., Melissa and Shawn Lynch are trying to salvage their home. In order to pay off credit card debts, they took out a second mortgage on the three-bedroom home they bought in 2001 for $71,000, but then were hit with medical bills on top of the new, larger mortgage payments. Three weeks ago, they sought help from a debt counselor and discovered that their house was at great risk. ''We were young,'' said Ms. Lynch, 28, and the lender ''smelled blood, really.''
 While not everyone affected is a poor credit risk, much of the booming business of debt consolidation focuses on such borrowers -- what is known as the subprime market. 
 The industry, which has an estimated four million outstanding loans, has enabled many people with modest incomes to own their homes. But last year, more than 16 percent of subprime mortgages were delinquent or in foreclosure. More than 76,000 families with subprime mortgages tumbled into foreclosure in the first quarter of 2004, and an additional 47,000 in the second quarter. 
 While statistical evidence is piecemeal, the rush to pay off credit cards and other consumer debt by taking out bigger mortgages appears to be playing a growing role in this trouble.
 Many people who refinance mortgages, of course, do so simply to lower their house payments. But the people who refinance for extra cash are as much as twice as likely to lose their homes through foreclosure than those who refinance for other reasons, according to statistics from the PMI Group, a major mortgage insurer. And most subprime loans being made today -- estimates run as high as 70 or 80 percent -- are debt consolidation loans like Mr. Knox's.
 ''Financing credit card debt on your mortgage, in general, is a bad idea,'' Edward M. Gramlich, a Federal Reserve governor, said in an interview last week. ''With the credit card debt you can go into bankruptcy, but if you put it on your mortgage you could lose your house, and that happens a lot.''
 Policy makers see the very existence of these debt-consolidation loans as the next issue in their battle with the subprime lending industry, which until now has been criticized largely about its high costs, prompting new state and federal laws. 
 Some industry officials say lenders have pushed too hard in selling dangerous loans to vulnerable homeowners who may not fully appreciate the risks. Larry Litton Jr., the chief operating officer of Litton Loan Servicing, based in Houston, which collects mortgage payments on behalf of lenders, said that most of the delinquent subprime loans he was handling involved debt consolidation and borrowers who did not realize that they would go back to running up more credit card debt unless they found some way to balance their income and expenses. 
 ''Even though, conceptually, debt consolidation is used to retire debt, it often leads to increased debt burden,'' he said. ''People make decisions sometimes that aren't real rational whenever it comes to incurring debt. I sure hate for people to draw conclusions that these people are irresponsible as a drug addict, but they are similar in the sense that debt can be very addicting.''
 William C. Apgar, an assistant housing secretary in the Clinton administration, said that homeownership ''can't be used as an everlasting reserve fund for folks who have more expenses than income on a perpetual basis.''
 But as the case of Michael Knox shows, many homeowners do use mortgage refinancing that way and some lenders have sold the maneuver aggressively to people hooked on the promise of easy credit. 
 Mr. Knox's story, pieced together from financial documents and from the increasingly despairing letters he wrote to company officials, regulators and others, is a particularly sad look at this dark side of the mortgage refinancing boom. 
 Mr. Knox may have seemed like someone you would not want to lend money to. But by the logic of the subprime market, he looked like a desirable customer.
 Subprime lenders charge higher-than-usual interest rates and can protect themselves by selling the loans to Wall Street, which in turn consolidates large numbers of loans into investment pools and markets them to investors worldwide in the form of asset-backed bonds. 
 But experts say that the market is susceptible to overzealous salesmanship and, sometimes, fraud.
 Mr. Knox had already refinanced twice in six months when he got the call from an Aames Financial broker. In qualifying Mr. Knox for a $90,000 mortgage at 9.23 percent that he ultimately could not afford, company records show, Aames waived its own rules for verifying income and employment. The mortgage was also based on an assessment of his house that was considerably higher than an official county estimate.
 Aames, a medium-size lender based in Los Angeles, said it had done nothing wrong in lending money to Mr. Knox, particularly because he had almost always paid his bills on time. As Aames pointed out to an arbitrator who ruled in its favor after Mr. Knox filed a complaint, ''No one was pointing a gun to his head to do it.'' More broadly, the company said it had stringent measures to avoid problem lending, including a system adopted last year to determine whether borrowers would truly benefit from its loans. 
 In April, the company disclosed that it was cooperating with a Federal Trade Commission inquiry into subprime lending practices nationwide. And in Iowa, the state justice department is investigating Mr. Knox's case, saying that it may show that the lending industry is undermining homeownership by pushing too hard for growth. 
 ''In addition to being appalled by what happened to Michael Knox, we are very concerned about appraisals that are inflated and we are very concerned about incomes that are inflated or completely made up,'' said Tom Miller, Iowa's attorney general.

Serial Refinancings
 Mr. Knox became a homeowner in 1988, using a traditional bank mortgage to buy a wood-frame house built in 1946 just north of downtown Des Moines. He paid $29,000 for 984 square feet; ownership was a huge achievement for him. ''He loved that house,'' said his daughter, Marlene Knox.
 Divorced and living alone after raising four children, Mr. Knox was anxious about money, people who knew him say. He had held various jobs, from welding grain elevators to working as a security guard at parking garages. But he increasingly suffered from depression, compounded by circulation problems, and his disability check of $1,068 a month left him perennially short of funds.
 A neighbor, Janet L. Bequeaith, recalled that he would often buy cream cheese on sale as a substitute for higher-priced protein. He also made his own furniture, dabbled in unlikely inventions and taxied people to the doctor for a few extra dollars. A financial high point came in 1998, when he won $15,000 in a game show sponsored by the Iowa state lottery. 
 But then he found a surer way to instant cash. Or rather, it found him. Credit card companies sent Mr. Knox blank checks, out of the blue, that he had only to fill out to get thousands of dollars. ''I tried to tell him that's not the way to operate,'' said Dennis M. Wilhelm, a neighbor. ''But he couldn't resist.''
 Mr. Knox opened charge accounts at Wal-Mart, Target and Sears. To pay utility bills and other expenses, he used credit cards from Providian, Wells Fargo and three other banks. His luxury was a desktop computer with an e-mail account, neighbors say.
 But eventually Mr. Knox was borrowing cash from one card to pay off another, and when he ran short he would grab a two-week loan from a storefront lender who charged interest at the annual rate of 520 percent.
 That was when he started refinancing his home -- first for $49,400 in September 2001, then for $67,000 in March 2002. Yet it was never enough.
 Aames's brokers hunt for customers by using lists of people who recently refinanced their mortgages. In telephoning these prospects, brokers said they asked about credit card debt, both as an incentive to refinance again and to increase their own commission with a larger loan.
 ''It's a dog-eat-dog world out there, and you do what you have to, to get loans,'' said Stephen Black, a former Aames loan officer in Tysons Corner, Va. ''You don't lie to your client, but you make them feel like you're their best friend and can be trusted.''
 Still, Mr. Knox posed something of a challenge. The real estate agent who sold him the house said its value had risen to perhaps $65,000, which the county confirmed in a recent assessment. That was not nearly enough to get Mr. Knox, who was already spending 55 percent of his income on his mortgage, the new loan he needed to pay off his bills.
 Six months later, in September 2002, Ames said it would lend him $90,900 based on a $101,000 valuation by an independent appraiser. Startled, Mr. Knox said he worried that his taxes would soar. But he later wrote to the arbitrator that Aames had assured him the appraisal would not be disclosed to the county. ''The appraisal was a complete sham,'' Mr. Knox wrote to the arbitrator.
 In an interview, the appraiser, Mark S. Wallace, said all appraisals were matters of opinion, and that he frequently resisted entreaties by lenders who wanted inflated valuations. He has surrendered his license to settle an unrelated case brought by regulators, state records show.
 Aames said it had the appraisal checked for accuracy through a consulting appraisal firm.

Who Wrote the Letter?
 For Mr. Knox, the new appraisal left a major problem. The bigger mortgage would raise his monthly payment to nearly $800, with taxes and insurance, from $643. But he got only $1,068 in disability from Social Security, and Aames required that his income be at least twice his debt.
 Mr. Knox's broker, Matthew Wright, who was then with Aames, first suggested inflating his income by creating a phantom renter, according to Mr. Knox's written account. When he balked, Mr. Knox wrote, Mr. Wright said he could claim income from his attempts to sell a mimeographed book on magic that he had put together.
 Mr. Knox wrote that ''I never made a dime trying to sell my books,'' but his loan papers -- which Mr. Knox later said he did not notice -- reported $820.42 in monthly income from book sales, putting his debt-to-income quotient at 49.9 percent, slipping just under the company's 50 percent cap.
 Still, Aames required additional proof of self-employment, and a reference letter appeared in his file from a local banker. The letter was a fabrication, The New York Times learned by calling the bank, which said the name of the banker on the letter was fictitious; no such person worked for the bank.
 Mr. Knox's family and friends say it is inconceivable that he concocted the letter. In an interview, Mr. Wright disputed each point in Mr. Knox's account of the loan and denied any involvement in the letter. ''I've never, ever committed fraud and never will,'' said Mr. Wright, who said he left Aames for a better opportunity shortly after Mr. Knox got his loan. ''If a customer tells me this stuff you have to believe it.''
 Experts estimate that fraud is at play in at least 20 percent of all loans that end up in foreclosure; inflated valuations are rampant, experts say, and appraisal trade groups say the system needs to be overhauled. Connie Wilson of AppIntell, a firm in Weldon Spring, Mo., that helps lenders avoid problem loans, said employees of the lender and others who profit from the loans are almost always involved in loans that later end up in foreclosure.
 Last month, the Federal Bureau of Investigation warned of a looming ''epidemic'' in mortgage fraud involving loan brokers, appraisers and lending officers. Its caseload of open fraud inquiries surged to 533 investigations in June from 102 in 2001. 
 Aames credits a hot line it set up in 2001 with exposing employees who improperly qualified borrowers. In other cases it was the borrower who discovered irregularities. A disabled elderly woman in Seattle who settled a case against Aames last year found fabricated letters and invoices in her file verifying income she did not have. 
 Whatever the precise origin of Mr. Knox's fake letter, Aames's rules require harder proof of self-employment, like a business license or advertising receipts. Aames said the underwriter who checked the loan had waived this requirement at his discretion.

A New Cycle of Debt
 Mr. Knox had expected the new mortgage to leave him free and clear. But borrowing $90,900 cost him $7,259 in fees and other expenses. After repaying his existing $67,000 mortgage and mailing $15,574 to his creditors, he still owed $3,800 in credit card bills.
 He did what most borrowers do in this situation, debt counselors say: he ran up more credit card debt. Even filing for bankruptcy on this new debt, which he did six months later, could not save his home. The mortgage alone was simply too big.
 ''My health has been ruined, my medical bills have gone up because of the stress this loan has caused me,'' he wrote to Aames.
 To consumer advocates, stories like Mr. Knox's show the need, at a minimum, for some government intervention to warn borrowers of the risk in this debt maneuver. With rising interest rates, some say the pressure on homeowners will only increase.
 ''Credit is not just a benefit; it is also a dangerous instrument,'' said Margot Saunders, a managing attorney at the National Consumer Law Center in Washington. ''Everything from cars to toasters that have some danger are regulated, but loans which can cause such devastation when provided in the wrong situation are not regulated.''
 Aames says it would object to any measures that unfairly restricted access to credit. ''It would be a great disservice to deny millions of prime and subprime borrowers the opportunity to tap into the equity in their homes to pay for important purchases and consolidate debt when the vast majority of these customers repay their loans,'' Ian Campbell, a spokesman for Aames, said.
 In a recent speech on subprime lending, Mr. Gramlich of the Federal Reserve warned that steps being taken to curb lending excesses would apply only to banks and other companies that are closely scrutinized by banking regulators, and not to independent mortgage companies.
 ''We as an industry do a lot of great things in providing liquidity,'' said Mr. Litton, the mortgage servicer. ''But the problem is, we often lose sight of common-sense things. Is it good business practice in principle to do three cash-outs in one year?''
 Mr. Knox pursued arbitration because his loan contract barred him from suing Aames. In November 2003, the arbitrator rejected his case without explanation. Aames, which said it received very few complaints about its loans, said it stopped requiring arbitration because of controversy over the practice.
 In Mr. Knox's case, the loan was sold to Bear Stearns, which says it offered to extend his payments to avoid foreclosure. Consumer advocates say such offers generally involve too little money to help people like Mr. Knox.
 Instead, he bought more lottery tickets. He visited the local casino. And when the foreclosure notice arrived, he phoned his brother, Christopher, in Arizona to say goodbye.
 ''I told him to come out with me,'' Christopher Knox recalled. ''And he said, 'I'm too old to start over again.''' 
 A few weeks later, in early March, he made a last call for help. He phoned a lawyer, and the lawyer contacted former colleagues at the state justice department and told them that Mr. Knox had a strong case. When an investigator there could not reach Mr. Knox, she phoned the police. They found his body in the car. 
 Last Thursday, the sheriff's office held an auction to sell Mr. Knox's home, which had an opening price of $64,200. Nobody bid on it. Bear Stearns will have to dispose of the property by itself.

HEADLINE: Teaching Mogul Tots to Swim, for the Rent and Stardom

BYLINE: By SUSAN CAMPOS

 BODY:
GIAVANNA SCHOEN entered the Beverly Hills estate of Irwin Winkler on a sunny afternoon in a scarlet bathing suit and flip-flops. Nodding familiarly to the gardeners, she headed to the enormous white-tiled pool evocative of old-style Hollywood, where Mr. Winkler waited with his two grandchildren. 
 Ms. Schoen flashed a megawatt smile and scooped up Maya, 4, for her weekly swim lesson. As Mr. Winkler, the legendary producer of ''Rocky'' and ''Goodfellas,'' looked on, Ms. Schoen coaxed his granddaughter into a proper stance for diving and encouraged her to swim to Ali the Alligator, a floating toy. 
 When the talk shifted to Ms. Schoen herself and her ambitions to be in the movies, Mr. Winkler said he had not heard that before. ''Now that you know I want to be a star,'' Ms. Schoen blurted out with trademark bravado, ''make me a superstar.'' 
 Ms. Schoen, one of Southern California's top private swim instructors, has taught the children of Jodie Foster and those of the actor Gil Bellows from ''Ally McBeal,'' among other celebrities. 
 Not coincidentally, she is also looking for her big break. She rarely misses an opportunity to chat up powerful Hollywood parents while teaching the crawl and the breast stroke to their children (and sometimes to foreign-born nannies).
 Starry-eyed new arrivals in Hollywood once sought jobs at restaurants like Spago or the Monkey Bar, hoping for a chance encounter with a director or producer. Ms. Schoen and many other tan, toned young men and women have found a better way to insinuate themselves: They have made the children's swimming coach a hot job for aspiring actors. 
 Ms. Schoen, 30, is a former lifeguard from Rockville Centre, N.Y., who has the body of a ''Baywatch'' extra and the sassy self-assurance of the actress Drea de Matteo. She worked as a cocktail waitress when she moved to Los Angeles four years ago. ''I met Bruce Willis, Denzel Washington and Tori Spelling,'' she said of that job. ''They knew my first name, but that was it.'' 
 At a wrap party for the television series ''Angel,'' on which she worked one episode as a body double, she met another struggling actress, who moonlighted as a swim teacher. The woman persuaded Ms. Schoen to sign up with her employer, a school called Aquasafe. 
 Two years later Ms. Schoen went out on her own and founded Splish-Splash Swimming, which employs three instructors besides her and teaches 42 children. The swimming season runs from May into October. Parents pay $40 for a 30-minute lesson with the guarantee that 2- and 3-year-olds will be afloat within 10 sessions and swimming across the pool the next year. 
 Meanwhile Aquasafe, now Ms. Schoen's competitor, has 30 teachers in the Los Angeles area, 90 percent of whom are trying to break into show business, said the company's owner, Tracy Carpenter. Few are former competitive swimmers. They are typically trained by more senior instructors and take a class in CPR.
 ''Actors are very versatile,'' Ms. Carpenter said. ''They're animated with children and used to taking direction. And they're usually unemployed, so they have very flexible schedules.'' 
 Until recently Ms. Carpenter was running Aquasafe from Mendocino in Northern California, using a Beverly Hills area code. Two weeks ago she opened an office in Los Angeles. Clients have included the actors Dermot Mulroney and Christian Slater, the producer Chris Moore of ''American Pie'' and the writer and director James Cameron. 
 Mr. Cameron, whose credits include ''Titanic'' and ''The Terminator,'' employs Amanda Ross to coach his two youngest children. Ms. Ross, 21, is a Missourian who said she is often told she looks like ''the cheerleader from 'American Pie.' '' (That would be Mena Suvari.) She has coached for the last two summers while attending film school in the San Fernando Valley. She said Mr. Cameron was aware of her lofty aims. ''James Cameron told me he'd take a look at my short film and pass it on to the person who's in charge of entry-level hiring at his production company,'' she said. 
 Another Aquasafe instructor, Krista Carpenter, has been treading water in Hollywood pools for 10 years. A former track star in a small Indiana town, Ms. Carpenter, 28, the sister-in-law of Aquasafe's owner, is one of the school's most popular teachers. Her most notable dramatic performance was as a high school student strangled in ''Murder by Numbers,'' a 2002 thriller starring Sandra Bullock. It was not a speaking role, but it was a screaming role, and thanks to numerous flashback scenes Ms. Carpenter enjoyed plenty of screen time. 
 Ambitious and seemingly indefatigable, Ms. Carpenter teaches 10 to 12 children during the day and stars in small theatrical productions at night. She is hoping her poolside connections pay off. ''I teach for several big names, and I feel like if I got to the level where I was in the finals, I'd have an edge,'' said Ms. Carpenter, who looks slightly like Reese Witherspoon. She was sitting in a shady area of a client's Westwood pool in a black one-piece suit, waiting for Shane, 3, to show up. 
 Shane's mother, Annette Davis, is a producer on the CBS sitcom ''The King of Queens.'' She said her toddler had tearfully rejected four swimming coaches until Ms. Carpenter came along. A couple of months later he was fearlessly paddling around the pool. Grateful, Ms. Davis has offered to give Ms. Carpenter a career boost. ''I asked Krista to give me a head shot,'' she said, while watching her son splash around. ''I'm happy to do what I can for her, since she's done so much for me. This is a tough business.'' 
 Unlike some other teachers, Ms. Carpenter only recently and discreetly began telling clients about her ambitions to be in front of the camera. ''I don't want to seem like I'm just teaching swimming to advance my acting career,'' she said. But sometimes she scolds herself for not being more aggressive.
 In Ms. Schoen's case, self-promotion knows few boundaries. Using the Internet Movie Database -- a Web site that lists credits and current projects for writers, actors and producers -- she keeps on top of her clients' careers. She is not shy about calling them at home or on their cellphones when she learns they are pursuing new movies.
 Few of the successful filmmakers interviewed about their children's swimming teachers voiced annoyance that breast-stroke lessons in the intimacy of a home pool might segue into a job pitch. It may be that this is the air one breathes as a big shot in Hollywood, where even the guy delivering your Chinese takeout hands over a script he has written. Barbara Dreyfus, a literary talent agent at United Talent Agency, who has had Ms. Schoen teach her daughter, but does not represent her professionally, said: ''She's relentless. She doesn't take no for an answer. She just needs one person to say yes.''
 One of Ms. Schoen's proudest moments was during the making of ''Phone Booth,'' which was filmed in Los Angeles but set in New York City. Ms. Schoen, who was an extra, approached the director, Joel Schumacher. ''I said, 'If you'd like a real, true authentic accent from New York, you have the real deal here, and I would love to have some lines in this movie,' '' she recalled. The next week she was given a speaking part. While her brief role was later cut, her residual checks still arrive. 
 ''I came out here 3,000 miles for one shot'' at stardom, Ms. Schoen said, shaking out her short wet hair at the Winkler pool. ''You've got to put yourself in front of these people.''
 Slipping her red-painted toes into the 85-degree pool, a smile quickly faded from her face. Ms. Schoen, whose proximity to so many Hollywood egos seems to have made her something of a diva herself, insists that the pools she teaches in never dip below a tepid 91 degrees. But Mr. Winkler, an avid swimmer, prefers cooler water. With an acting career to consider, Ms. Schoen decided to relax her rules. 
 As Mr. Winkler watched Maya swim across the pool, he had nothing but praise for her instructor. ''You've got to be talented to do what she does,'' he said. ''She has a specific skill.'' 
 Charles Winkler, his son and producing partner, spoke encouragingly about Ms. Schoen's prospects. ''When the part is right and the time is right, Giavanna will be in one of our movies,'' he said. 
 He has delivered on such promises before. One of Ms. Schoen's fellow instructors, Ian Nelms, is already doing business with the Winklers. A year ago Mr. Nelms and Eshom Nelms, his brother, made a short film for $1,500 called ''Squirrel Trap.'' After a swimming lesson one day, Ian Nelms gave the movie to the younger Mr. Winkler, Maya's father. Impressed, the Winklers hired the brothers to do the trailer and music videos for the DVD of ''De-Lovely.''
 ''It's because he's talented,'' Irwin Winkler said, adding that teaching swimming is ''a good opportunity to meet people, but if you don't have the goods after that, it doesn't do you any good.''
 Ian Nelms, 25, a former wrestler from Bakersfield, Calif., has also caught the attention of another client, the screenwriter and producer John Strauss, whose credits include ''There's Something About Mary.'' Mr. Strauss has two boys taking lessons with Mr. Nelms, and he has read his scripts and watched his film. ''I think he absolutely has a future as a writer-director,'' Mr. Strauss said. 
 Mr. Nelms met his friend and employer, Ms. Schoen while relaxing at the swimming pool of the Hollywood apartment building where they both lived. He was waiting tables at Tony Roma's in Beverly Hills. Ms. Schoen offered him more freedom and more money to come work for her. ''I was just doing it because I like to coach children and thought it would be nice to be stuck in the pool all day,'' he said. ''I had no idea it would lead to all of this.''

HEADLINE: Energy Prices Rose. So Did These Funds.

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
IT was a rough third quarter for most stock mutual funds, but some achieved solid gains, particularly funds with energy holdings that benefited from the run-up in oil and natural gas prices. 
 Managers of three of the top-performing diversified funds that have no loads, or sales charges, and are open to new investors talked about their choices -- and their views on the market for the rest of the year.
 Looking for Profit Surprises
 The $840 million CGM Focus fund returned 7.16 percent for the quarter. Its manager, G.Kenneth Heebner, 64, said he looked for ''companies with bigger earnings or faster earnings growth rates than investors had expected.'' The fund, which holds about 25 stocks, can be more volatile than more diversified portfolios. 
 CGM benefited from rising commodity prices during the quarter, Mr. Heebner said. About 40 percent of its assets are invested in gas, oil and oil services stocks, and 18 percent in steel stocks.
 Among its winners was Amerada Hess, the oil and gas company, up 12.4 percent. The rising price of oil has increased the company's earnings estimates, Mr. Heebner said. He forecasts oil prices of $45 to $65 a barrel next year because OPEC countries cannot produce enough to satisfy the growing demand in China and elsewhere in Asia.
 The fund also made money in Nucor, a steel manufacturer based in Charlotte, N.C. Shares rose 19 percent in the quarter. Chinese demand for steel drove up global prices and created higher earnings for the company, Mr. Heebner said.
 Continued strong earnings growth drove up the share price of Mobile Telesystems, a provider of cellphone services in Russia and Ukraine. Shares of the company, which is based in Moscow, rose 18.8 percent in the quarter, and the stock is still cheaply priced, he said, because of ''skepticism about the business environment in Russia.'' 
 Mr. Heebner does not share that skepticism and calls himself ''neutral'' on the overall United States market, which he says is fairly valued. Energy and raw materials companies should continue their strong performance, he said. 

A Good Bet on Commodities
 Rising commodity prices helped the $180 million Permanent Portfolio fund earn 6.13 percent in the quarter. Michael J. Cuggino, 41, the manager, says the fund helps protect investors from unfavorable markets or geopolitical events. 
 Morningstar Inc. classifies it as a conservative allocation fund, meaning that it keeps 20 to 50 percent of its assets in stocks and 50 to 80 percent in fixed-income securities and cash. 
 The fund made money in gold bullion and coins (20 percent of the fund's assets), investments in Swiss government bonds (10 percent), and natural resource and real estate companies (15 percent).
 Rising prices for gold, oil and other commodities helped the fund's profitability, Mr. Cuggino said, adding that commodity prices were being propelled by ''supply constraints and ever increasing worldwide demand.''
 One winner was ChevronTexaco, the big oil company; its shares rose nearly 50 percent in the quarter. Besides benefiting from rising energy prices, the company is able to pass on higher costs to consumers.
 ''It's one of the few industries with pricing power,'' Mr. Cuggino said. 
 Its dividend yield is almost 3 percent, and it repurchases shares regularly, he said, ''giving money back to shareholders rather than reinvesting in further production at inflated prices.''
 Rising copper prices helped Phelps Dodge, the copper producer based in Phoenix. Its shares more than doubled in the quarter. ''It's a classic story of supply constraints and increasing demand,'' Mr. Cuggino said. The company's costs of production have been decreasing as its operations have become more efficient, he added.
 Another winner was the Ryland Group, a home builder based in Calabasas, Calif. Ryland specializes in the market for first homes, focusing on the Southwest and the Southeast. ''Interest rates have been low for quite a while, so more people are opting to buy rather than rent,'' Mr. Cuggino said. While the Federal Reserve has increased short-term interest rates, he added, longer-term rates have been steadier. Ryland's shares rose 18.5 percent in the quarter.
 Geopolitical questions will keep energy prices high, Mr. Cuggino said. And uncertainty in the United States about the presidential election and the direction of the economy will keep the markets unsettled for months, he added.

Dividend Payers Take Off
 The $82 million Philadelphia Fund returned 4.61 percent in the quarter. Its manager, Donald H. Baxter, 61, said the fund started in 1923, presumably in Philadelphia, and has changed hands several times. He is based in Boca Raton, Fla.
 Mr. Baxter says he aims to minimize risk by investing in stocks, particularly dividend payers, that he believes are reasonably valued. That has been difficult lately, he said. 
 Its dividend-paying stocks have rallied recently, Mr. Baxter said. The fund made money in public utilities, which account for 23 percent of its assets. One winner was TXU, a gas and electric utility in Dallas. 
 In February, TXU brought in a new chief executive, C.John Wilder, who has been restructuring its operations, selling off assets and reducing debt, Mr. Baxter said. Shares of the company rose 18.3 percent in the quarter.
 The fund also made money in oil companies, which account for 20 percent of its assets. It owns shares of ChevronTexaco and Occidental Petroleum, an oil and chemical company based in Los Angeles. Shares of Occidental, which has operations around the world, rose 15.5 percent in the quarter. 
 ''Anything to do with refining has done well,'' Mr. Baxter said, adding that ''the price of chemicals has gone up along with the price of gasoline.'' 
 Mr. Baxter says he expects that individual sectors of the economy will continue performing strongly, especially banks and public utilities with steady businesses. 
 ''I'm expecting long-term interest rates will continue to fall a bit, and the economy will continue to grow at a reasonable rate, but somewhat slower than we've been accustomed to during good times,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Cash Is a Dirty Word In Some Value Funds

BYLINE: By ILANA POLYAK

 BODY:
ROBERT TORRAY says he's finding plenty of value in the market these days. As the manager of the $1.6 billion Torray Fund, he has invested every available dime in stocks and does not have anything left over in cash.
 ''I don't see any risk in stocks at all,'' Mr. Torray said. ''I'm a long-term investor. I'm thinking 10 years down the road.''
 His willingness to commit himself fully to stocks at current prices sets him apart from many traditional value investors, who are holding substantial cash reserves. Also known as deep-value investors, members of this group say they will buy a stock only if its price is at a substantial discount to its true worth, including tangible assets, earnings and money in the bank. At current prices, many value managers say, they are not finding bargains. 
 ''I'm looking for companies that are trading at substantial discounts,'' said Steven Romick, manager of the FPA Crescent fund in Los Angeles. ''I don't feel like I have to buy a company that to me doesn't represent value, just because I have cash on hand.'' 
 Forty percent of Mr. Romick's $700 million assets are in cash. His colleague, Robert Rodriguez, manager of the FPA Capital fund, has 33 percent of its assets in cash. The team that runs the Clipper fund, also of Los Angeles, has 27 percent in cash; and Jean-Marie Eveillard and Charles de Vaulx, managers of the First Eagle Global fund, have 23 percent.
 Mr. Torray, who describes himself as a value investor of a very flexible kind, says that even if stock prices are a bit high, they will be offset by multiyear gains. Over the last year, Mr. Torray said, he has plowed cash into stocks like Amgen, the biotech company; Illinois Tool Works, which makes plastic car parts and welding equipment; and J.P. Morgan Chase, the global bank. 
 By some measurements, though, stock prices are not cheap. The average price-to-earnings ratio of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is 16, based on prospective earnings, higher than the long-term average of 14. But that gap does not scare off Mr. Torray. At the current valuation, he figures that the stock market's rise plus dividends will beat the return of a 10-year Treasury bond, which yields a bit over 4 percent. 
 ''All these assets compete with each other,'' he said. ''You've got to be invested someplace.''
 In fact, several managers of portfolios that are commonly classified as value funds say that even if today's market prices do not meet a traditional definition of value, they are justified by low interest rates and low inflation. If anything, favorable economic conditions make the market look inexpensive from a long-term perspective, said William H. Miller III, manager of the $14.5 billion Legg Mason Value Trust. By some measures, he said, stocks are selling at a 20 percent to 30 percent discount to their fair value.
 If stocks are not the screaming bargain that they were in the summer of 2002, when ''everyone was throwing stocks out the window,'' Mr. Miller said, there are still plenty of opportunities for value investors. ''The market doesn't get cheap unless there are a lot of problems,'' he said. ''Stocks don't get cheap when dividends are growing, when cash flow is strong, when balance sheets are strong, the way they are now.''
 Mr. Miller's sanguine view of equities has led him to hold less than 1 percent of his fund's assets in cash. He has been positive about the market for much of the year, adding to his position in Eastman Kodak stock, which fell over the last few years as the company made a transition from film to digital photography. At $32.22 on Sept. 30, the shares sold for less than half their level of five years ago. He also bought shares of InterActiveCorp, Barry Diller's portfolio of e-commerce businesses. The company generates close to $1 billion in annual free cash flow and dominates the market in most of its business lines. It was down 35 percent for the year through September.
 Mr. Miller is best known for beating the S.&P. index for 13 consecutive years, though his fund was trailing by more than four percentage points through September, largely because of his holdings in technology companies, including Amazon and Nextel, and a lack of investments in energy stocks.
 Mr. Miller, and managers like Brian Rogers, of the $15.8 billion T.Rowe Price Equity-Income fund, acknowledge that their bets may not pay off for a while. 
 ''I accept the possibility that returns aren't going to be stellar by historical standards,'' said Mr. Rogers, whose fund holds just 3 percent in cash. ''But I don't see extreme risks. I'm making the bet that a portfolio of companies trading at reasonable prices is going to outperform two-year Treasuries.'' 
 Edward Maran, associate portfolio manager of the $2 billion Thornburg Value fund, says that he, too, is happy to buy stocks that are cheaper than they were a few years back, even if they do not fit the strict definitions of value investing. 
 ''If you look at a company like General Electric, over the last five years it has a trailing P/E of 30,'' Mr. Maran said. ''Right now it's trading at 21 times trailing earnings. That's a value.''
 By the same measure, Mr. Maran and his co-manager, William Fries, have picked up shares of Microsoft, Southwest Airlines and ExxonMobil. In many cases, the dividend yields of the stocks they buy beat the returns of short-term bonds.
 SOME financial advisers say they do not want fund managers to hold much cash. ''Before we invest in a fund, we've already determined what amount of a person's portfolio should be in equities,'' said Chitra R. Staley, chief investment officer of the financial planning firm Mintz Levin in Boston. ''So when the manager starts to raise large sections of cash, that means that our asset allocation is no longer valid.''
 Others, like Harold Evensky, a financial planner at Evensky, Brown & Katz of Coral Gables, Fla., say that managers who dart in and out of the market had better know what they are doing. ''We respect managers that have opinions,'' Mr. Evensky said, adding, ''That's what we hired them for.'' But he said they would be held to the same standards as those who invest all their assets. 
 Hoarding cash until an investment window opens is a form of market timing, skeptics say. According to Ibbotson Associates, missing the 10 best trading days during the five years from 1989 through 1994 would have reduced a portfolio's average annual gain to 4.3 percent from 10.3 percent. Missing the 20 best days would have produced an average annual return of just 0.14 percent.
 That's the kind of situation that Harry Cohen and Scott Glasser, managers of the $5.5 billion Smith Barney Appreciation fund, say they want to avoid. Their portfolio holds 8 percent cash, which they have raised in order to offset capital gains ahead of their Oct. 31 fiscal year-end. They do not claim to be able to time the market and, from their perspective, prices are reasonable.
 ''We go through our portfolio and there's nothing we don't like,'' Mr. Cohen said. ''I don't understand why you'd want to be 25 percent in cash now.''

HEADLINE: A Manager Falls Hard, But Sticks To the Path

BYLINE: By CHERYL STRAUSS EINHORN

 BODY:
GARRETT VAN WAGONER, one of the hottest mutual fund managers of the 1990's, is grappling with some very serious issues. His style of investing has gone out of vogue, the returns on his funds are terrible, and some of his shareholders are suing him. 
 What is worse, in August, Helane Morrison, the district administrator in the San Francisco office of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said that his firm had ''betrayed the trust investors place in mutual fund directors and managers to report their funds' market values accurately.'' Mr. Van Wagoner and his firm, Van Wagoner Capital Management, agreed to pay $800,000 to settle S.E.C. accusations that they had defrauded shareholders and mispriced securities. 
 As part of the settlement, Mr. Van Wagoner also agreed to step down as president of the company and will be barred from serving as an officer or director of any mutual fund company for seven years. He neither admitted nor denied any wrongdoing, and continues to manage three mutual funds. 
 So what effect has all this had on his approach to fund managing? None, Mr. Van Wagoner says. ''We are going to stick to our knitting,'' he said. ''It isn't fair to shareholders to change strategy. For better or worse, I am still managing my funds on a day-to-day basis and picking stocks.'' 
 Since the Internet bubble burst, Mr. Van Wagoner's fund company has stuck to its strategy of investing in tech companies, and has consistently lost money. The company's five mutual funds had $3 billion in assets under management in early 2000. There are only three funds left, now with just $185 million in assets. This year through September, these funds all had negative returns: Emerging Growth was down 36.16 percent, Small Cap Growth was down 34.91 percent and Growth Opportunity was off 28 percent. 
 Over the longer term, the numbers are also dismal. The flagship Emerging Growth fund gained 291 percent in 1999, but it has lost more than 25 percent, annualized, over the last five years, putting it among the worst performers in the Morningstar fund database. By comparison, the Nasdaq composite index has lost about 7 percent, annualized. 
 Mr. Van Wagoner says he is convinced that his investing approach will pay off again. 
 ''Now, we're doing the same thing,'' he said. ''We have not changed our theme or thesis.'' 
 Some tactics have changed, though. The funds are still invested mainly in tech stocks, but the shares do not change hands as often. The average holding period for a stock was once about three months; now it is six. And Mr. Van Wagoner said that his penchant for buying illiquid, private companies was gone. Today, he said, ''we're basically out of that business with no intention to return.'' 
 IT was Mr. Van Wagoner's illiquid investments that got him into trouble with his auditors and the S.E.C., whose rules require that no more than 15 percent of a fund's assets be in private companies. In 2001, Mr. Van Wagoner surpassed that. Susan LaMarca, a lawyer in the enforcement division at the S.E.C., said that when Mr. Van Wagoner exceeded the limit, he deliberately mispriced the private securities, marking them down sharply to try to get them back under the 15 percent mark. This ''resulted in misvaluing the funds,'' she said, leading to the S.E.C. action. 
 His Emerging Growth fund had nine investments in private companies whose values were suddenly and drastically marked down. Those included Comergent, an e-business software maker, and Kestrel Solutions, an optical networking company. At the end of 2000, well into the tech crash, these investments were being valued at almost $29 million, more than their purchase price. Six months later, Mr. Van Wagoner said they were virtually worthless at the time; he marked down their total value to just $9. 
 Mr. Van Wagoner says he stayed in the market too long. ''Our mistake was not selling at the top,'' he said. As stocks became pricier in 2000, he said that he worried and wanted to sell but did not have the courage to do so. 
 ''The major driver of overall performance of our funds is determined by small-cap high-growth technology, health care and consumer companies,'' he said. ''We're hostage to that by design. In the go-go years of 1999-2000, our shareholders benefited from spikes in stock prices and equally are hurt now by the same thing.''
 The funds have come under criticism not just because of Mr. Van Wagoner's investing judgment, but also because of the funds' governance. The board of Van Wagoner Funds has only two members. Both are independent, but neither owns any stock -- something that Christopher Traulsen, a Morningstar senior analyst, calls ''a red flag,'' raising issues of whether the board is aligned with shareholders. Mr. Van Wagoner said the structure of the board ''avoids conflicts.''
 But Mr. Traulsen added: ''Most fund boards have at least four to five people. I'd never seen a board like this before. It is so small and they don't have any money in the funds -- not a single dollar.'' The Van Wagoner Funds also have among the highest fees in the industry, an average of 2.19 percent, on an asset-weighted basis, compared with 1.44 percent for mutual funds over all, according to Morningstar. 
 Burton Greenwald, an industry consultant, said: ''It will be very difficult to rebuild credibility. Van Wagoner was a high-profile personality, and without making changes in personnel and broadening his product line, I think it will be very hard.''
 Mr. Van Wagoner has not made significant changes in personnel, and he narrowed his product line by shuttering two funds a year ago. As for his credibility, Mr. Van Wagoner said he did not believe that it was an issue. ''With people who already know me, I don't have to rebuild anything, but with strangers I need to do it through an improved information flow and performance,'' he said. 
 As for the funds' poor showing, he said the firm was reliant on the overall performance of tech stocks. The tech-heavy Nasdaq composite index was off about 5 percent this year through September.
 For his mutual funds, Mr. Van Wagoner seeks companies with a stable profit margin and revenue growth of 20 percent or more a year. He said he favors wireless telecommunications. ''We believe there is growth there,'' he said, citing Novatel Wireless, which provides wireless modem cards for computers, Ditech Communications, which makes products to improve cellphone reception, and Alvarion, a radio antenna company. Shares in these companies make up about 10.5 percent of the holdings of each of the three funds. 
 HE also holds shares of eBay, the online auctioneer; Yahoo, the Web portal; and Qualcomm, which makes software and chips for digital wireless communications. Mr. Van Wagoner says his funds are good vehicles for investing in technology and innovation. ''If you are comfortable to be in risky, cutting-edge stocks, then we could be a part of your portfolio,'' he said.
 But some analysts say that after Mr. Van Wagoner's missteps, investors should be wary. ''It is difficult to argue you should invest with him,'' Mr. Traulsen said. ''The risks are so high, and his fall from grace has been so far, that it is hard to justify the role of a fund like this in a person's portfolio.''

HEADLINE: A Full-Service Nest for Fledgling Companies

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS 

 BODY:
A SHIFT is taking place in the executive suites of an office building here that was once home to major corporations like I.B.M., AT&T and Prodigy Services, and where the chief executives plotted the future of their companies. Now the president of SalesWorks, Ben Blumberg, schedules seminars for his fledgling sales-training enterprise, and the owner and president of DocuServe, Chris Kalian, strategizes for the future of his rapidly growing document services company.
 ''We're still talking about potentially influential C.E.O.'s,'' said Adam J. Stark, 31, who opened Stark Business Solutions in late September to provide space for companies like Mr. Blumberg's and Mr. Kalian's, ''but the difference is that these days their companies are much smaller.'' 
 He has leased part of the 11th floor of the office building at 445 Hamilton Avenue and is providing space and services to companies that are expanding but not yet ready for large quarters or long-term leases.
 Since the early and mid-1990's, when downsizings, mergers and acquisitions sharply altered the number of employers, the overall percentage of small businesses in the county has been rising. In 2001, the most recent year for which the county has figures, 80 percent of Westchester establishments had fewer than 10 employees, and 90 percent of all companies employed fewer than 20. Such figures intrigued Mr. Stark.
 ''When I began digging into the data, I noticed that almost all of the county's growth was occurring in the small-business sector,'' said Mr. Stark, whose new undertaking is geared toward home-based businesses that often require professional settings for meetings and conferences. Such businesses include lawyers and financial consultants who primarily work in New York City but who are also establishing second offices in Westchester, as well as women returning to work after taking time off to raise families.
 In contrast to other landlords who lease part-time office and conference space on a ''pay as you need'' basis, Mr. Stark is offering a package of services to go with the sublease space, including e-mail, domain hosting, printing, catering, accounting, Web design, marketing and public relations.
 Smaller businesses that need such services are considered the backbone of Westchester's current economy, said Salvatore J. Carrera, the county's director of economic development.
 ''It's nothing new to rent out just offices and furnishings,'' Mr. Carrera said. ''We've seen that before. But this represents something different in Westchester. It's one-stop shopping for young companies.'' He said he did not know of any other company offering a space and services package. 
 For $99 a month, for example, a business owner can join Stark Business Solutions, and is entitled to rent office space, is listed in the lobby directory, is given a mailbox and can use other services as needed. A typical executive might spend $200 to $400 a month for some part-time office space, phone service, appointment scheduling and other such arrangements. Accounting services are also available for $200 a month; customized Microsoft PowerPoint presentations at $40 an hour; and phone service and appointment scheduling, each for $75 a month.
 Mr. Stark first became aware of the need for a concierge-type service for emerging companies several years ago when he helped his wife, Marisa, start up a small jewelry company. ''I realized how complicated the process of beginning a business is,'' he said. ''You see many people who are good at what they do, but they're not good at running a business. And how do you go about finding the right lawyer? What about your bookkeeping needs?''
 As a mergers and acquisitions adviser before this venture, Mr. Stark witnessed the beginnings of a new trend toward smaller companies. ''I saw a lot of people breaking away from larger companies and starting up on their own,'' he said. ''They believed they could do it better on their own, and often in six or seven years, they were as big as the company they left behind.''
 And while working out of one's house may seem like a practical solution for a start-up, that often delivers the wrong message to clients, Mr. Stark said. ''When you have an office in a Class A building, there's the subtle impression that you give your clients that you're for real,'' he said, pointing out one of his marketing strategies. He currently has three full-time employees.
 Mr. Blumberg, the owner of SalesWorks who had been working from his home in Larchmont, is about to settle into a 170-square-foot office with windows in Mr. Stark's complex, moving in his computer and personal effects like photos of his wife and children. ''Before, I always had to meet clients at their office, or rent a room at a hotel for a meeting,'' he said. 
 As one of Mr. Stark's first clients, Mr. Blumberg has a two-year agreement to use an office with a view of the growing city of White Plains, and on a clear day it even offers a glimpse of the New York City skyline. 
 Mr. Kalian, of DocuServe, said the 130-square-foot space from Mr. Stark provided growing room for his company, which already has other office space in White Plains. With his BlackBerry and his laptop, he said, he can set up an office almost anywhere. 
 A third-quarter report issued the first week of October by Newmark & Company Real Estate showed that the vacancy rate for office space in the central business district of White Plains was 15.6 percent, compared with 22.1 percent for the third quarter of 2003. Some of the slack was later taken up by small and mid-size technology-related companies -- until when the dot-com industry crashed and rates once again rose. 
 In tapping into the revitalization of downtown White Plains, Mr. Stark is aware of the cyclical nature of the economy and of the inherent risks. He has a long-term lease for more than 7,000 square feet in the building, which has weathered many economic ups and downs and periods of vacancy. He won't disclose how much of an investment he has made in his new business, only that ''it's substantial.'' But a comparable class A office space in White Plains rents for more than $20 per square foot. 
 With money in the bank from the career he pursued when was in his 20's, Mr. Stark said, ''If I didn't do it now, I probably wouldn't do it at all.''
 ''I don't want to look back and regret not doing it,'' he said, ''and if I didn't come up with this idea, someone else would.''

With the help of Stephen Samuels, below right, Ben Blumberg makes a new office his own. (Photographs by Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Hard Look at Yonkers

 BODY:
You think it's fun being mayor? Look how Philip A. Amicone suffers in Yonkers. 
 Everyone's a critic. People say his financial plan doesn't add up, just because one little chunk of it -- O.K., $200 million -- is fictional. The mayor says the fault is not his but Albany's, where he says lawmakers have shortchanged Yonkers for years. But the state budget director is not buying it. She rejected his plan in September, calling it unrealistic. 
 People concerned about the schools are saying mean things, too. Parents, teachers and other district employees are furious about a $25 million hole in the school budget that Mr. Amicone tried to close with imaginary money. Imaginary money, of course, can be spent only on imaginary teachers, librarians and security guards. But when the school year started, hundreds of real people were fired. That left the schools staggering under the effects of drastic layoffs and program cuts. 
 Now the N.A.A.C.P. wants a court to determine whether the cuts have harmed school programs that were established under a settlement agreement to lift student achievement. Mr. Amicone's critics fear the city may be violating the settlement. That would be just what the mayor needs -- more trouble with a federal judge.
 The second-guessing does not stop there. Politicians with ties to Yonkers -- State Senator Nicholas A. Spano; Assemblymen Richard L. Brodsky, Gary Pretlow and Michael Spano; and City Council members John M. Murtagh and Dee R. Barbato -- have gone public with their concerns about Mr. Amicone's money problems. The local paper has pointed out numerous ways that the mayor and his allies have been piggy with city finances and lax with conflict-of-interest rules -- taking no-bid city contracts for sideline businesses, for example, and driving around in sleek, city-leased S.U.V.'s. Even the Chamber of Commerce president has weighed in, joining others who have frowned at the tangled web connecting Mr. Amicone and his City Hall friends with various autonomous, unaccountable institutions set up to promote development in Yonkers, notably the Yonkers Industrial Development Agency. 
 The agency and various spinoff corporations -- whose members include Mr. Amicone; his predecessor, John R. Spencer; and a few friends -- have been moving around millions of dollars for a range of projects in Mr. Amicone's strapped city. Do these ties constitute a conflict of interest, and could the money that flows to these corporations be used in better ways to patch Mr. Amicone's tattered budgets to benefit all the residents of Yonkers?
 It's all so confusing. But help is on the way. Alan G. Hevesi, the state comptroller, already has his hands full with a financial crisis at Westchester Medical Center and a school district scandal on Long Island. But he's a sharp money guy, and if anyone can get to the bottom of the Yonkers muddle, he can. Mr. Amicone may have been too shy or proud to ask for help. But those politicians named above were not, and since they asked, Mr. Hevesi has agreed to audit Yonkers's books. He is starting with the city's overall financial operations, and may expand his investigation into other areas, like the schools and the industrial development agency. 
 Perhaps the Hevesi investigation will yield good news for Mr. Amicone, because if everything the mayor says about how he runs Yonkers is true, then the numbers -- hard, solid, audited numbers -- will bear him out. And that will finally get the grumblers, do-gooders and naysayers off his back. The the investigation could also turn out badly for the mayor. Either way, we can only hope that Mr. Hevesi's arrival is the beginning of the end of Yonkers's troubles.

HEADLINE: Rockefeller Drug Laws

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Re ''An Eye on Albany'' (editorial, Sept. 26):
 The recent lopsided Albany primary win of P. David Soares, who made reform of the Rockefeller drug laws the centerpiece of his campaign, indicates that New Yorkers are aware of and opposed to the dreadful Rockefeller drug laws, which mandate long prison sentences for nonviolent drug offenses.
 Ill conceived from their enactment 30 years ago, the laws' social and economic consequences have been devastating -- the ripping apart of families and communities, and the ruin of individual lives. Mr. Soares's victory makes it clear that the number of people who accept the laws' mistaken premises and shamefully racist results is rapidly decreasing. Unfortunately, the ones with the power to change the laws -- the unaccountable triumvirate of Gov. George E. Pataki, Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, and Sheldon Silver, the Assembly leader -- are in this shrinking group.

Mary-Elizabeth Fitzgerald
Park Slope, Brooklyn

The writer is executive director, JusticeWorks Community.

HEADLINE: Zoning Changes, No. Parking Garage, Yes.

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 The Ridgewood Chamber of Commerce's proposal to amend zoning ordinances to limit the number of banks, restaurants and personal-services businesses in downtown Ridgewood (''Too Much of a Good Thing?'' Oct 3), is an asinine way to address our current shortage of parking for shoppers.
 Instead of proposing more restrictive zoning ordinances, which might burden an already frazzled zoning board, prompt expensive legal challenges and curtail future economic growth, chamber members' time and efforts would be better spent lobbying the Ridgewood Village Council to expeditiously build an adequately-sized, off-street, municipally-owned-and-operated parking facility.
 If leaders of local private-and public-sector groups would collaborate and focus their collective energies on this solution, perhaps the construction of a parking garage will not fall through this time as it has so many times in the past.

Boyd A. Loving
Ridgewood

HEADLINE: Thoughtful Gifts

BYLINE: By Edward McPherson

 BODY:
In 1879, Friedrich Nietzsche wrote: ''Merchant and pirate were for a long period one and the same person. Even today mercantile morality is really nothing but a refinement of piratical morality.'' What, then, would the philosopher make of seeing his likeness on a Nietzsche's ''Will to Power'' Bar? 
 For the last 10 years, modern pirates calling themselves the Unemployed Philosophers Guild have been toiling in their cave under the Manhattan Bridge, turning the faces of the great philosophers, artists and writers into commercial plunder. ''I was very surprised this took off,'' says Stephan Shaw, one of the company's founders. The guild has come a long way since Shaw and his brother, David, sold homemade earrings -- depicting both sides of the German reunification debate -- in SoHo. Back then, Shaw begged his mother to make a prototype for a silk-screened pillow with Edvard Munch's painting ''The Scream.'' When a catalog company ordered 5,000 more pillows, Mom said, ''I'm not making them.''
 This year, the guild expects to gross $1.75 million. Its catalog features Little Thinker dolls (a heavy-lidded Poe; a prim Emily Dickinson) and finger puppets of luminaries like Kierkegaard and Gandhi, as well as assorted Freudiana: pillowcases inscribed with chapters from ''On Dreams,'' and Freudian slippers. There is also an assortment of Shakespeareana -- watches, ties -- and the Will to Power Bar, ''the official nutritional supplement of the 'superman.'''
 What next? ''I would love to do Hegelian dialectics in finger-puppet form,'' Shaw says. The guild does have plans for Adam Smith's Invisible Hand: in essence, clear plastic in the shape of a hand. On the back, Shaw will print an argument claiming there is no such ''invisible hand,'' which is perhaps something the market will bear out, as people part with their money just to prove it to themselves. Go to www.philosophersguild.com. EDWARD MCPHERSON
