HEADLINE: Redeploying In Gaza Strip, Israel Finishes Its Pullback

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
Israeli troops and armor completed their pullback from built-up areas in the Gaza Strip early on Saturday, but many soldiers have remained in the territory, redeployed on the hills overlooking the Jabaliya and Beit Hanun refugee settlements.
 The redeployment was the effective end to Israel's 17-day offensive to repress the firing of Qassam rockets into Israeli settlements and towns from the northern Gaza strip. Some 115 Palestinians died during the operation, Israeli Radio said Saturday morning. Western news agencies say at least a third of the dead have been civilians caught in the crossfire, including two schoolgirls killed by stray fire as they sat at their desks. 
 Israeli officials emphasized that forces would remain on high alert and would be prepared to retake positions on the edges of Jabaliya and other refugee areas if rocket attacks resumed in earnest. The troops are redeployed about a half-mile into Gaza, in the area from which many of the rockets have been fired by Palestinian militants, most of them affiliated with Hamas.
 ''We will move in and act whenever we feel there is a threat,'' said Raanan Gissin, an adviser to Prime Minister Ariel Sharon. 
 The pullback produced celebrations throughout the northern Gaza Strip, especially in Jabaliya, which exploded with firecrackers. A Hamas spokesman, Fathi Hammad, said: ''The Zionist army has retreated in defeat from all the positions. We consider it a victory for our resistance.''
 But the Israeli operation also left behind further destruction to the shaky economy of Gaza. Troops uprooted many olive and citrus groves -- having already uprooted many earlier this summer in Beit Hanun -- from where the militants can hide to fire the Qassams, an operation that can take less than 10 minutes.
 Electricity was out in Beit Hanun, Palestinians said, houses were destroyed in Jabaliya and roads and water pipes had been ripped up by tanks. ''The whole house is rubble and there is no way we can find anything,'' Ezzeya Daher, 50, told Reuters news agency in Jabaliya, as hundreds of people picked through mounds of debris to search for belongings. ''Now we are refugees for a second time.''
 Senior army leaders have argued for a week now that the goal of completely ending the rocket attacks is impossible without taking over the densely populated Jabaliya camp, which is more like a poor urban neighborhood, at great danger to both troops and civilians. Remaining in static positions is also dangerous, the army argued, and Mr. Sharon finally agreed to the redeployment on Thursday night.
 Pressure on Israel was also increasing from foreign governments, especially from the Bush administration and the European Union, to end the operation, which was beginning ''to seem disproportionate,'' as one American State Department official said. 
 Part of the army's goal, officials said, was to hit hard at the leadership and infrastructure of Hamas, Islamic Jihad and Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades in Gaza, which had built up considerably in the last four years. The army, with extensive use of camera drones and helicopter gunships, killed a number of militant commanders and destroyed metal factories and workshops where rockets are made, army officials said.
 The army also wanted to send a sharp message to the West Bank: that Israel would not tolerate the Qassams anywhere in the Palestinian territories.
 In that sense, one senior Israeli official said Saturday, ''the operation can be called a real success.'' But it is not necessarily over, he said. In another sense, the operation had a political value, the official admitted -- with Mr. Sharon proving that despite his intent to pull nearly 8,000 settlers from Gaza, he intends to protect Israel and its interests. In a symbolic vote against his opening speech to the Parliament last week, in which he talked of his plan to withdraw unilaterally from Gaza, 15 of 40 members of his Likud Party voted against him, abstained or refused to vote. Mr. Sharon faces an important vote for real on his plan on Oct. 25.
 Compared to the Palestinian dead during the Gaza operation, Israeli losses were small: three civilians, including two children killed by a Qassam in Sederot, two soldiers and a Thai farm worker.
 On Friday night a Palestinian woman, 75, was shot dead while eating her dinner, breaking the fast of the first day of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan. The Israeli military said it was investigating the incident and was not sure where the gunfire originated.
 More details emerged from one of the most shocking incidents of the operation, involving the shooting of a 13-year-old Palestinian girl. Soldiers said their company commander broke the rules of war by firing a magazine into the head and body of the girl, Iman al-Hams, to ''verify the kill'' after she approached an outpost near Rafah.
 A field investigation concluded that there was no evidence to substantiate the charges, but the army chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Moshe Yaalon, suspended the commander on Friday. 
 The commander, a captain, was suspended for severe operational errors, army officials said, including leaving his post, bringing other soldiers away from the post, firing in panic at the ground, showing poor leadership and allowing a bad atmosphere in the company.
 The military police are conducting a separate investigation, and the commander is likely to be court-martialed, the officials said. The field commanders concluded that soldiers at the post did not see the commander shoot the girl but had made operational errors themselves by letting her approach so close to the outpost before seeing her. They also noted that the soldiers had a history of bad blood with the commander.
 The soldiers said they suspected the girl of carrying a bomb to the outpost; her family said she was lost on the way to school. Her schoolbag contained only books.

LENGTH: 1964 words

HEADLINE: Cheaper by the Half-Dozen? Hardly

BYLINE: By JENNIFER GOLDBLATT

DATELINE: MARLBORO TOWNSHIP 

 BODY:
FOR 32 weeks, Elizabeth and Eric Hayes the parents of two sets of twins -- waited nervously. They marked the calendar with an X, a heart and a ''thank you'' for each day that passed uneventfully.
 Then, a few minutes after 1 a.m. on Wednesday, Sept. 14, in Long Branch, six new residents beat some very long odds. In a span of two minutes and 47 seconds, the 37-year-old Ms. Hayes gave birth to six babies -- born about six weeks early -- who are believed to be the state's first surviving sextuplets: Tara, Rachel, Rebecca, Ryan, Connor and Eric Jr.
 So this, to understate matters, is a number story. 
 For instance, the parents had a 5 percent chance of conceiving sextuplets, and the babies had a 50 percent chance of gestating long enough to survive outside the womb. Indeed, the chances that the babies would be healthy were so low that the parents held off on desperately needed shopping and home improvements, fearing that if something went drastically wrong, they would be surrounded by reminders of their loss.
 ''It was the most strenuous eight months of my life,'' Mr. Hayes, 38, a drug abuse officer with the Marlboro Township Police Department, said a few days after the babies arrived -- a gasp escaping as his words registered. ''I know it's going to be hard. I don't know how we'll do it. But we'll figure it out.''
 They had about three weeks to figure it all out. By last week, the last of the six infants, Rebecca Mary -- who was born four pounds and three ounces and was kept hospitalized a bit longer than the others -- was brought home to the cacophony that is the Hayes household these days. 
 Every family accepts that the moment a child enters the world, the rest of life must be put on hold. Cries for food, sleep, comfort and a clean rear end take precedence. But when those cries are multiplied by six, answering those cries requires mastering the principles of mass production.
 Such will be the world of Elizabeth and Eric Hayes of Morganville, New Jersey's newest statistical anomaly.
 Consider this: Each day, approximately 60 bottles of formula must be prepared, served and cleaned. In the first year, the Hayeses will need to put on, change and toss out 17,520 diapers -- give or take any number of emergencies. They will go through 26,520 pre-moistened wipes -- again, subject to an infant's temperamental digestive system. Keeping straight six different sets of allergies, tempers and medications will require coding, sorting, infinite patience and a healthy sense of the absurd.
 Even nail clipping will be a production. After all, there are 60 fingers and 60 toes to deal with.
 Then there is the matter of simply going out, which will resemble the movement of a small army with fully stocked, industrial-sized diaper bags and car seats all around for the couple's two aging minivans, each of which has nearly 200,000 miles.
 Although the family belongs to Sam's Club and Costco, only so much can be bought in bulk; after all, they live in a house, not a warehouse off Exit 8A of the Turnpike.
 And that is the easy part, because they will still have to figure out how to finance the needs of 10 children on a policeman's salary.
 Just nine hours after the Hayes sextuplets were born, newspapers, magazines, radio and television stations inundated the Monmouth Medical Center requesting interviews and photographs (Oprah among them).
 Forget the sextuplets and two sets of twins, ages 6 and 8. Managing the sudden celebrity can be one of the biggest immediate challenges, says Maureen Doolan Boyle, executive director of Mothers of Supertwins, a nonprofit support network based in East Islip, N.Y. 
 Parents do not want to be diverted from their family's needs, Ms. Boyle explained, yet such attention often results in offers of community and corporate support -- which has fallen off as the number of multiple births has increased and the economy has softened.
 ''It's a tough thing,'' Ms. Boyle said. ''You don't want to miss out on any possible opportunity and at the same time you need to stay on and nurture your family and stay on top of the medical issues that come up.''
 The usually private Hayes family has been glad to satisfy the media's interest -- to a point. The hospital called a news conference on Sept. 15, the day after the children were born, and hired a local public relations company owned by a former classmate from Marlboro High School to handle all calls and create a Web site -- www.thehayes6.com. 
 In the first four weeks after the children were born, Mr. Hayes agreed to telephone interviews while his wife was recovering. But even in the weeks the babies spent in the hospital before coming home, he kept photographers and potential interviewers at bay. He and his wife did not have the time, he said, and they needed to focus on caring for their four other children and preparing the house for the stampede.
 ''It's a little overwhelming,'' Mr. Hayes said.
 After all, the four other Hayes children -- Kevin, Kyle, Kieran and Meghan -- have needs of their own. Mr. Hayes said the twins adore their new brothers and sisters, and have each picked out a baby that resembles them. He plans to have at least one night a week of one-on-one time out of the house for each of them, though a trip to Disney World they were saving for is off.
 In Marlboro, the close-knit community where Mr. and Mrs. Hayes grew up, some neighbors have already lent support. A friend donated car seats. A local mother of quadruplets started a diaper drive. A stranger mailed the Hayes family a set of hand-sewn bumpers for each of the cribs. The Marlboro Township Education Association raised $1,600 for the family. Officers with the Marlboro Township Police Department donated vacation days to Mr. Hayes so that he could be off until January. And the Ross division of Abbott Laboratories agreed to donate a year's worth of formula to the family.
 But the family did not receive the blizzard of cash and gifts some people assume is forthcoming when such a bumper crop arrives. That is why Annette Sherman organized the diaper drive.
 ''When I had my kids, everyone was telling me, 'Call Pampers, they'll give you diapers for life,''' said Ms. Sherman, who has 6-year-old quadruplets and a 15-year-old daughter. ''And it's just not like that.''
 Mr. Hayes -- who is going to have to support a family of 12 -- said that he has heard rumors that his children's college tuition has been paid for. And he has heard grumbling from some who have criticized him and his wife for contributing to overpopulation and looking for handouts.
 ''Nothing could be further from the truth,'' an exasperated Mr. Hayes said.
 With that, he turned his attention to more pressing concerns. He certainly has enough.
 Many parents of triplets, quadruplets, sextuplets (pick a number, any number) find themselves vastly outnumbered, in need of armies of volunteers to help feed, change and hold the babies -- all the while attending to the needs of the older children. But even that is complicated. Infants born prematurely are vulnerable to respiratory syncytial virus, a flu-like illness that can be fatal and highly contagious. So the volunteers must be healthy and conscientious. And accepting help means sacrificing even more privacy.
 ''It's an institutional existence,'' said Kate Gosselin, of Wyomissing, Pa., who has about 50 volunteers helping with her 5-month-old sextuplets and her 3-year-old twins. ''One of our bathrooms is like a public restroom because so many people are in and out of it. There are notes and signs Scotch-taped everywhere. That's just not normal.''
 Then they will have the risks any new parent takes. After the Gosselins had their sextuplets, Mrs. Gosselin lost her job as a nurse and Jonathan Gosselin, a network engineer, lost his. Though companies donated everything from diapers to home improvements, the Hayeses still have mortgage payments to make.
 ''We're scraping the bottom of the barrel,'' Mr. Gosselin said.
 Yet as difficult as life might seem now, mothers who have been through this assured them that it was possible to survive the experience with everyone remaining healthy and retaining their sanity.
 ''The amazing thing is that with everyone working together, the babies seem to adjust to what the parents can do,'' said Janet Bleyl, a mother of 21-year-old triplets from Stockton, Calif., and president of the Triplet Connection, a nonprofit support group.
 Becki Dilley, of Berne, Ind., who gave birth to the country's first surviving set of sextuplets in 1993, sounded shockingly relaxed as she reflected on her family's early years. Sure, Ms. Dilley conceded, she and her husband did not get a lot of sleep. But each baby's personality quickly emerged, so she and her husband learned how to juggle feedings, changings and naps. 
 There were even benefits to having lots of children at once. When it came to toilet training, the toddlers who caught on quickly set a positive example for the others, she said. 
 And the rules of run-of-the-mill parenting still apply, Ms. Dilley added. For instance, it helps to have a deep friendship at the root of the marriage, where one spouse can sense when the other needs a nap, and when a crisis calls for teamwork. There are mini-honeymoons when the children pass crucial milestones -- such as when they learn to feed themselves, and when they learn to say, not wail, what they want.
 And as soon as it starts to seem easy, the children evolve once again, and a new challenge crops up. 
 ''You'll feel like you have to cut corners, but ultimately the children will be just fine,'' said Mrs. Dilley. ''You just can't do all the things you think you should. You've got to pick the most important things. And just enjoy the time.''
 In giving birth to sextuplets, the Hayes family has joined a growing number of couples who, assisted by fertility technology, are experiencing the joys and headaches of child rearing in exponential proportions.
 While still relatively rare, the rate of children born as higher-order multiples, (triplets, quadruplets, quintuplets, sextuplets or more), has jumped by nearly 400 percent in the last two decades, according to the National Center for Health Statistics. In 2002, 7,401 babies were born in sets of triplets or more, up from 1,337 in 1980. Twinning rates have climbed by 65 percent in that time, while the number of single babies born has edged up just 10 percent.
 After having two sets of twins, Mr. and Mrs. Hayes yearned for another child. They used ovulation induction treatments, which stimulated the ovaries to produce more than one egg. The treatments improved the chances that the couple would successfully carry one baby, but also carried the risk that they would have more than one. 
 ''We would have been happy with one,'' said Mr. Hayes.
 Once doctors realized that the 37-year-old mother was carrying a set of six, they gave the couple the option of reducing the number of fetuses, a procedure that protects the health of the mother and improves the chances that any of the babies will survive. Often with higher-order multiples, the babies do not get enough room to properly grow, increasing the risk of miscarriage. 
 In addition, such babies are typically born prematurely, increasing the likelihood that their hearts, brains and lungs will not be fully developed. And a mother who is carrying that many fetuses faces threats of hemorrhaging; diabetes; pregnancy-induced high blood pressure that comes with swelling, sudden weight gain, headaches and changes in vision; and cardiovascular complications. 
 Despite the risks, the couple forged ahead.
 ''If I took pictures of our four kids, and someone said, 'Pick one of these to get rid of,' I couldn't do it,'' Mr. Hayes said. ''If it wasn't going to happen, it wasn't. We knew the risks and we accepted it.''

 Elizabeth and Eric Hayes with newborn sextuplets. They already have two sets of twins. (Photo by Gary Gellman)(pg. 1)Drawing (Drawing by Dave Klug)(pg. 9)Chart: ''Back Up the Diaper Truck: Care and Feeding Tips''While it is still relatively rare, there are an increasing number of couples who are having triplets, quadruplets, quintuplets and sextuplets. For those parents, meeting the basic needs of the babies in their first weeks of life requires that the parents master economies of scale and principles of mass production while managing the very special needs of their babies, who are often born premature. Here are some suggestions from Maureen Doolan Boyle, executive director of Mothers of Supertwins, a support network in East Islip, N.Y.FeedingIn the beginning, the children will probably need to be fed every two to three hours. If possible, have three adults around at all times so that two people can be involved in feeding and the other person can be making bottles, changing diapers, preparing for the next feeding or meeting the needs of another baby who might have reflux, projectile vomiting or gas. It can take from 45 minutes to an hour to finish feeding and changing one baby.SleepAt first, the babies are going to be sleeping, eating and going to the bathroom -- with a limited amount of wakeful periods. Consider having some sort of white noise in the bedrooms, like an air-conditioner or a radio to help diminish the sound of disturbing noises like garbage trucks or flushing toilets. If possible, have three people available around the clock until the babies weigh about 10 pounds. Have a 20-watt bulb in the room for sufficient light to change diapers but not bright enough to wake the other babies. Have an electric cooking pot filled with water in the nursery to warm the bottles so you do not have to go downstairs. Make sure to restock the diapers, the wipes, extra clothes and the burping cloths before you go to sleep.ComfortIt's impossible to spoil a premature infant with attention. Research has shown that massages can help the rate of weight gain and development.DiapersOne of the biggest concerns for parents of premature infants is Respiratory Syncytial Virus, a highly contagious coldlike illness that can be fatal. With so many bowel movements, burping and throwing up going on under one roof, it is important that everyone in the house is healthy and that everyone washes his or her hands between changing the babies.(pg. 9)

HEADLINE: The Dollar Is Defying Both Expectations and Gravity

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
THE dollar is confounding investors again and nibbling into their returns from abroad. And some forecasters say that the currency will continue to hold its own and even rally into next year, creating another headache for investors with a taste for foreign stocks and bonds.
 The dollar's strength is surprising, given the record deficit in the country's trade and services with the rest of the world -- known as the current account. That deficit could easily become a major drag on the dollar if foreigners curtail the hundreds of billions they invest in the United States each year. 
 So far, though, the unexpected rise of the dollar has hurt investors who bet it would fall for the third consecutive year. Instead, the dollar has gained 1.9 percent against the Japanese yen and 1 percent against the euro so far in 2004. It is also up 2.9 percent against the Australian dollar and 2 percent against the Mexican peso.
 When euros are translated back into the stronger American dollar, the 3.2 percent climb in France's CAC 40-stock index this year becomes a gain of just 2.2 percent. Similarly, the 2.9 percent gain in the Nikkei 225 index becomes an increase of just 0.9 percent. Those performances are still better than that of Wall Street but not as good as what would have been expected with a weaker dollar. 
 (The big exception is Canada: There, a vibrant economy, a strong commodity base and a trade surplus with the United States has pushed the American dollar down 3.4 percent, turning a 6.9 percent return on the Toronto stock exchange into a 10.7 percent return.)
 The current account deficit has to be covered by the inflow of funds from abroad into American assets, including Treasury securities, corporate bonds and stocks. Many economists suspected that this flow from abroad would begin to slow, setting off dollar selling as investors sought to beat a decline in the currency -- and a climb in interest rates.
 The current account has been worrisome enough that four top Federal Reserve officials have talked about it since September. Some said that the dollar could be pushed sharply lower if the deficit gets out of hand. 
 One of the four, Robert D. McTeer Jr., president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, said in a recent interview, ''I wasn't trying to convey the idea that it was a clear and present danger.'' He also said that the sequence of remarks was not coordinated. ''It was no conspiracy,'' he said. 
 Nonetheless, the comments by the Fed officials -- also including Janet L. Yellen, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco; Ben S. Bernanke, a Federal Reserve governor; and Roger W. Ferguson, Jr., vice chairman of the Fed -- pulled the dollar lower.
 David Gilmore, a partner at FX Analytics, explained the confluence of comments this way: Central bankers, he said, are just ''drawn to commenting on significant structural imbalances, like moths to a flame.''
 So far this year, the net flow of money from abroad is running ahead of last year's pace. Through July, according to the latest available Treasury data, the net flow was $500 billion, which would work out to an annual total of $857 billion, compared with $711 billion last year. That would easily outdistance the current deficit, which would total $627 billion, based on the quarterly average for the first half of this year.
 Robert Sinche, global head of currency strategy at Bank of America, says that there is another explanation for the dollar's resilience, at least against the euro: the improvement of interest rate differentials in favor of the United States. In January this year, based on the futures market, the expectation was that three-month interest rates in the euro zone would be as much as 0.65 percentage points higher than comparable American three-month rates by year-end. 
 By the end of June, the expected differential had narrowed significantly, and is now hovering around 0.08 percentage points in favor of the United States. ''That is a big shift in expectations,'' Mr. Sinche said.
 AGAINST the yen, the dollar has remained strong, although the Japanese in March stopped their extraordinary intervention in support of the dollar. The Japanese government had sought to prevent the yen from rising in value and curbing Japan's exports. The dollar has held up anyway, Mr. Sinche said, partly because foreign capital flows into Japan have slowed.
 Mr. Sinche said last December that the dollar would rise against the euro this year. Now he is predicting that the dollar will weaken in the beginning of next year, then rally, leaving the euro's value around $1.15 by the end of 2005; it is now about $1.25. As for the yen, he projects that the dollar will be in a range of 110 yen to 115 yen next year; it is now at 109.30 yen.
 If Mr. Sinche is right, foreign stocks and bonds will have to attract American investors on their own merits in coming months -- without the expectation of a boost from the dollar.

HEADLINE: Inching Along, One More Piece To Rebuild Iraq

BYLINE: By JAMES GLANZ

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
Call it the Iraqi version of the tortoise and the hare.
 On a six-day journey this week, more than 500 tons of house-size components on their way to the capital crept across Al Anbar Province, a grimy and murderous border region, at the white-knuckle pace of 10 to 15 miles an hour. Protected by an armada of helicopters, Bradley tanks, Humvees and bulletproof Land Cruisers, the convoy looked like the makings of some kind of space program, but in fact it carried sections of an enormous generator, financed by American taxpayers, to upgrade the Iraqi power grid. In operations like this, Iraq's physical reconstruction inches forward.
 But lined up against the reconstruction effort is the danger that strikes with seemingly inescapable suddenness all over Iraq: in one recent example involving a similar convoy, two Jordanian drivers working for the company whose trucks move the generators were gunned down. 
 Pressure is increasing on the Bush administration to show that the rebuilding effort will win this race, and that some of the many projects that have been delayed or temporarily abandoned will soon improve the lives of Iraqis, giving them a reason to trust the government and reject the anarchy of the insurgency.
 More than any other sector of the infrastructure, it is the electrical grid that fills officials with hope. True, virtually every project is behind schedule, and few goals have been met. Indeed, officials involved with reconstruction expend great effort revising the overly optimistic projections made by the American occupation authorities in previous months. But there are, finally, more megawatts on the grid than before the invasion, and with a number of big projects under way behind the scenes, officials say it is just the start.
 ''We're getting the crisis back under control,'' said Simon Stolp, the program manager for electricity at the Project and Contracting Office, which is managing billions of dollars of Congressionally mandated reconstruction money. ''There are a whole basket of positive things to be seen,'' he said.
 The grid had been deteriorating under the pressure of sanctions and neglect ever since it was put back together after American bombers destroyed it in 1991, but Mr. Stolp said those problems were quickly becoming a thing of the past.
 ''There will be more megawatts on the grid next summer than there have been at any period of time since the gulf war,'' Mr. Stolp said.
 Iraqi electricity experts are less impressed. Saad Shakir Tawfiq, a scientist who leads Iraqi teams working at several power plants, said he was surprised that his relatively upscale Baghdad neighborhood was still subjected to regular blackouts, two hours off, and four hours on.
 ''It's the time of year when everybody switches off air-conditioners, and nobody uses heaters,'' Dr. Tawfiq said. ''There should be a surplus.''
 But Mr. Stolp said that Iraqis, with their newfound freedom, were buying more and more electrical appliances and sapping the network, and even Dr. Tawfiq conceded that it could take a while for the big generation projects to get more electricity into the homes of Iraqis. 
 The 340-mile journey the generator convoy took from Jordan, which a reporter joined for the final 75 miles, showed how determined the Americans are to push ahead with big electricity projects.
 The mission passed within a few miles of the insurgent strongholds of Ramadi and Falluja before the convoy of 42 vehicles reached Baghdad, snaking its way through the city's edgy streets in the dead of night. Workers climbed ladders to snip overhead power lines that were in the way, bulldozed obstacles on the ground and fixed a tank that had broken down in the convoy's path.
 Gunshots rang out repeatedly, although most of them came from American soldiers firing into the air to keep traffic back.
 ''This is one of those you'll-never-get-it-done tasks,'' said John Yourston, a former member of the British special forces and now the operations director in Iraq for Olive Security, a private company that directed the journey, from scouting out the route to positioning the tanks traveling in the convoy.
 The military's shorthand for the mission was MOAG, for Mother of All Generators. ''It's a monster, isn't it?'' Mr. Yourston said.
 The MOAG, along with a giant gas turbine to power it and two other huge truckloads of equipment, arrived intact at a south Baghdad power plant at first light on Wednesday morning, two days before the start of Ramadan.
 The generator is one of a pair manufactured by General Electric that are now set to be installed at the south Baghdad plant as part of a project to add more than 200 megawatts to the grid. That would more than double the current output of the ancient steam turbines at the plant and contribute substantially to the roughly 5,000 megawatts that the entire country is producing at the moment, said Abdul Hassan Qasim, the plant's director.
 ''What is produced by this turbine,'' Mr. Qasim said of the latest delivery, ''is essential to Baghdad, because it is in the heart of Baghdad.''
 So the juice will go right to power-starved consumers without being dissipated in long transmission lines, he said. David DeVoss, a spokesman for the United States Agency for International Development, which is administering the financing, said the estimated cost for the project was $162 million. Bechtel, the international engineering and construction giant, manages the work for the agency.
 Originally scheduled to be producing electricity by December, the generators are not expected to be ready until June. The pace slowed and security costs soared after the insurgency broke out across the country in April. Two months later, three General Electric employees were killed by a suicide bomber while riding in a convoy in Baghdad.
 Now the work site, which employs some 260 Iraqis, resembles Fort Knox, as one Bechtel employee put it. (Fearing reprisals, the company asked that none of its employees be named, and that no photographs showing landmarks around the compound be taken.) The site is surrounded by high concrete blast walls, and there is a bunkerlike inner perimeter where project managers work.
 Whenever a Westerner ventures from the inner perimeter and mingles with the Iraqi workers, he is accompanied by rifle-toting guards from ArmorGroup, another private security company. In addition, the site is protected by about 80 of the Nepalese guards known as Ghurkas. There are guard towers, checkpoints and sandbagged refuges for protection in case of a mortar attack.
 Like the Western managers and engineers, all of the security personnel must be fed and housed at the site. ''Security threw this project all out of whack,'' said a Bechtel official working inside the compound. ''There's no telling what it's going to cost.'' He cautioned, however, that not all of the cost increases could be attributed to security. Officials involved with the reconstruction say they are in negotiations with General Electric over cost increases. 
 Mr. DeVoss said he had no information on how much of the contract would be eaten up by security, but other officials say the proportion has risen to 30 percent and higher on similar projects.
 Still, it seems unlikely that an exact reckoning of security costs for the MOAG will ever be made. At various times the convoy was protected by the Army's First Cavalry Division; the Second Battalion, 11th Marine Regiment; and at least three other military units. Capt. Charley Von Bergen of the Marines guessed that 500 soldiers had been involved in one way or another, but he conceded that there was no solid estimate. Through it all, the MOAG kept rolling along, stenciled along its bottom edge with the word ''fragile'' and the universal sign for equipment that is easily damaged -- a wineglass.

HEADLINE: The Prestige HBO Series Is Going South

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES 

 BODY:
A PSYCHOTIC serial killer is on the loose in a harsh, soulless city, and the police are stumped. It's a familiar plot from a familiar genre, but among the things that make ''Epitafios'' different from the average television thriller is this: it is the first dramatic mini-series that HBO has ever commissioned in Spanish, and it was written and filmed in Latin America by Latin Americans with Latin American viewers in mind.
 On the air in the prime-time slot of Sunday night at 10 since mid-August, ''Epitafios'' (''Epitaphs'' in English) admittedly does feature a world-weary former cop as its main character, along with a few other conventions of the genre. But the 13-episode series has also emphasized some distinctly Latin American plot elements and production strategies with an eye to helping HBO raise its profile in a market that at times has proved difficult to penetrate.
 ''After years of being HBO's little brother, operating in a much smaller territory in terms of subscribers and economic strength than our domestic side, we needed to initiate a process parallel to what HBO did in the U.S. and generate our own programming,'' said Luis Peraza, a vice president of HBO Latin America who also is executive producer of the series. 
 Latin Americans, though, are raised on soapy telenovelas, which draw huge ratings everywhere they are broadcast, and have little exposure to thrillers other than what comes from the United States. Thus the choice of ''Epitafios'' as HBO Latin America's first effort was risky, as the directors and writers responsible for the show knew from the start.
 ''The Americans do the thriller a lot, and they do it well, whether in films, on television or in cable, and with more resources than we will ever have,'' said Alberto Lecchi, a veteran of film and television who is one of two directors of the mini-series, filmed in Argentina with an Argentine cast. ''So the first challenge we had to face was how to tell a story that has been told many times before and still, on the budget we had, glue the viewer to the screen.'' 
 One solution was to give the main characters traits that would be recognizable to viewers in the 20-plus countries where ''Epitafios'' is broadcast. Renzo Marquez, the former police detective turned cabdriver who is the protagonist, may be disillusioned, but he and the ex-colleagues he rejoins after his name appears on the killer's hit list are anything but hard-boiled. 
 ''We can't forget that we're in Latin America, with all the self-destructive processes and impulses that go with that fact,'' said Jorge Nisco, the other director of the series. ''These are not American or European characters. They are more passionate, with more exacerbated sensibilities, given to emotional explosions and not hiding their sentiments, whether love or fear or euphoria.''
 To make ''Epitafios'' even more realistic to HBO Latin America's two million or so subscribers, the series takes place in a world where the police ''lack the means to investigate, which forces them to improvise,'' said Walter Slavich, one of the scriptwriters. ''This isn't 'C.S.I.,''' he added, meaning that patrol cars run out of gas and forensic experts do not have the money to run tests that could help them crack the case. 
 Mr. Slavich and his twin brother, Marcelo, the other scriptwriter, also devised some unusual plot twists they hope will hook viewers. ''Epitafios'' not only features ''a killer chasing a police detective and not vice versa,'' as Mr. Lecchi noted, but also allows the identity of the killer, who has been knocking off teachers, students and administrators at an elite private school, to be revealed at the end of the third episode. 
 ''We wanted to be provocative,'' Marcelo Slavich said. ''We know the spectator is going to say, 'How can that be?' It's a different way of doing things, and I think it works. The audience knows the identity of the killer, but not why he kills or how the story turns out. And because the spectator knows who the killer is and the characters don't, we make the spectator an accomplice.''
 Once those issues were resolved, the producers then had to grapple with the problem of whether the actors should speak with Argentine accents, which are heavily Italianate in intonation and use some words and grammatical structures that are not common elsewhere. In the end, they decided to have the cast try to speak in what Mr. Peraza called ''neutral Spanish'' and to minimize Argentine inflections.
 ''It was very strange in the beginning, very odd,'' said Julio Chavez, who plays Renzo Marquez. ''I didn't think it was really necessary, but then I'm not the producer, so it's not my area. But what I could and did do was to grab the script and try to eliminate as many as possible of the usages that felt peculiar to me.''
 Similarly, though the setting of ''Epitafios'' is clearly Buenos Aires, with scenes set in identifiable local landmarks like Recoleta Cemetery, where Evita Peron is buried, the city's name is never once mentioned. ''We don't refer to the place because we want to tell a story that could take place in any Latin American metropolis,'' Mr. Nisco explained.
 As the series progresses, a brassy, burned-out detective named Marina Segal, played by Cecilia Roth, emerges as Renzo Marquez's bete noire turned ally. Ms. Roth, probably best-known outside Argentina as one of the muses of the Spanish film director Pedro Almodovar, hasn't worked much in television in recent years, but said she was attracted by the novelty of the ''Epitafios'' project and the challenges it presented. 
 ''We felt a little bit like lab rats in an experiment, in that we were aware that we were doing something new and very different,'' she said. 
 HBO Latin America is not seen in Spain, but there is already interest there and in other European countries in showing ''Epitafios'' on cable or broadcast channels. The show's producers recognize that in the United States the English-language audience that watches ''The Sopranos'' and ''Six Feet Under'' is a very hard sell. But they hope to reach the booming Hispanic market directly through the network's Spanish-language channel, HBO Latino. 
 ''We don't have a deal yet, but we are in discussions with HBO Latino,'' Mr. Peraza said. ''HBO domestic is more difficult for anything not spoken in English, but HBO Latino is very interested and we are very optimistic. Whether sooner or later, we are expecting some remuneration from our investment.''
 So far critics and audiences have embraced the series. There may even be an ''Epitafios II.'' But even if there is not a second season, Mr. Chavez already sees a spillover effect, both into network television here and across borders. 
 And regardless of the fate of ''Epitafios,'' HBO plans to plunge ahead with more original programming from other countries in Latin America. The network has already commissioned a pair of mini-series to be made in Brazil. The first, based on a character created by the Brazilian novelist Rubem Fonseca, is tentatively scheduled to go on the air a year from now and will give Spanish-speakers a glimpse of their giant Portuguese-speaking neighbor. 
 ''This is the good side of globalization, one that offers us the possibility for growth,'' Ms. Roth said. ''It is a good way for us to come together but at the same time see how we are different. The English-speaking world has been doing this sort of thing for a long time, but in Latin America, we have been distanced from each other. So this is an important step forward.''

HEADLINE: Old Goods Help to Bring New Liveliness

BYLINE: By C.J. HUGHES

 BODY:
SINCE the Third Avenue Bridge over the Harlem River closed two years ago, some drivers detoured onto Bruckner Boulevard have undoubtedly slammed their steering wheels in frustration. But others stuck in traffic in the Port Morris neighborhood in the South Bronx may be sitting up and taking notice. Unlikely as it may once have seemed, Bruckner Boulevard between Third Avenue and Willis Avenue has a surprisingly welcoming look. 
 Gone are the bombed-out buildings, shuttered storefronts and squeegee street brigades. Here instead are restored 1910 red-brick row houses and a growing parade of antiques stores. Facing them, old piano factories now house architects and accountants, breathing new life into a wheezy street. 
 Much of the sprucing up started nine years ago, when the city invested $500,000 for Belgian paving stone, pear trees and benches. Now, with new banners strung to lampposts announcing ''Bruckner Antique & Arts District,'' the street seems to have decisively moved beyond the days when Tom Wolfe used it as a set piece of 80's urban decay in ''Bonfire of the Vanities.''
 Bruckner has long been used by drivers heading to Manhattan from the north and seeking to bypass the Triborough Bridge tolls. Now, stuck in traffic, they can finally peek around, and the area is introduced to a whole new audience. ''Any retail area thrives on visibility, and we can now catch your eye when you drive through,'' said Neil Pariser, senior vice president of the South Bronx Economic Development Corporation, nicknamed SoBro. City leaders say the new bridge will be open next March.
 There are 11 antiques stores alone in this three-block stretch, squeezed between the Major Deegan Expressway and the Harlem River. Another antiques store will soon open on the corner of Bruckner and Alexander Avenue, and piggybacking on what's already there, woodworking, upholstering and refinishing stores have also set up shop.
 On weekends, families from Connecticut stroll the sidewalks, showing that the antiques industry can be a force for revitalization, bringing out-of-town dollars to hard-hit former manufacturing areas. 
 Denise Cruz, who owns Custom Design, a furniture and upholstery business on Bruckner, said that one morning a year ago a woman from Manhattan who was lost discovered the store, and later spent $15,000 to repair couches and chairs. ''Unfortunately, though, we don't see sales that big all the time,'' Ms. Cruz said. 
 Whereas the rehab of Bruckner's south side has been fairly small-scale, on the north side, it's writ large.
 Kelly's Furniture at 20 Bruckner Boulevard sells ''furniture rugs gifts'' from a cavernous 30,000-square-foot block-deep showroom, with an attached 135,000-square-foot warehouse in a 1900 building that used to store beer for the Ruppert Brewery.
 In 1999, the company's owner, Clyde Kelly, nearly sold his buildings to Morgan Stanley but agrees that Bruckner's cleanup has kept his business afloat. ''The antiques stores have brought more sophisticated customers up here,'' said Mr. Kelly, who grew up in Mott Haven. ''It's very symbiotic.''
 Creative reuse of commercial space is also a priority at 40 Bruckner, an arched two-floor, 60,000-square-foot building where Borden used to stable milk-delivery horses. There, the owner, D. Benedetto Inc., which has owned the site since the 40's, has moved a deli and upholsterer onto the first floor, although the second floor is still empty.
 At 26 Bruckner, all but 6,000 of the 86,000 square feet on its top five floors has been leased, for rents that average $14 to $22 per square foot. The owner, Bradford N. Swett Management, which owns properties from Brooklyn to the state of Wyoming, hopes to get a restaurant to pay $12 a square foot for a 4,000-square-foot space on the ground floor, according to the assistant property manager, Christopher Gallagher.
 The city announced on Oct. 4 that it was beginning a public review to rezone 11 blocks in the neighborhood from industrial to mixed use -- similar to the zoning on the antiques side of the street -- so that people can live and work there while existing factories hum nearby. Mr. Gallagher said it would be only a matter of time before people discover, or rediscover, the area. 
 So far, residential development in this part of the neighborhood has mainly been confined to the dozens of units in the top three floors of the row houses. These are almost fully occupied, landlords said.
 The Clock Tower building on the corner of Bruckner and Lincoln is also being converted to residences. An imposing former piano factory, whose renovation continues, it has lured people from Manhattan looking for more space and cheaper rents. 
 If Port Morris ever matures into a more multifaceted neighborhood, old furniture should take some of the credit, said Mitchell Moss, a professor of urban planning at N.Y.U.'s Wagner School. 
 ''The city can encourage conditions that make an area naturally attractive, but you have to let the market work,'' Professor Moss said. ''Antique stores came onto Bruckner, and now the zoning is trying to catch up with them.'' 
 Some residents of older sections of the neighborhood have expressed concern that improvements may cause people to be priced out of the area. For its part, the Bronx borough president's office said that community meetings have given residents plenty of chances to speak out about changes to their neighborhood.
 ''I absolutely believe that a balance can be achieved that benefits the existing community and the new influx of people and businesses,'' Adolfo Carrion, the Bronx borough president, said in an e-mail.
 For merchants like Rafael Ramirez, owner of Zion Antiques, which specializes in lamp shades, bed frames and American and Latin-American oil paintings, it will take a long time for rents to climb anywhere near what he was paying in Manhattan. At his old store on West 25th Street in Chelsea, Mr. Ramirez was paying $3,500, while he now pays $1,200 for a 150-square-foot space that he occupied last December. 
 And even if gentrification pushes the rents up in the neighborhood, Mr. Ramirez, a 14-year resident of the Bronx, would not complain. ''I would be glad not just for the Bronx to improve,'' Mr. Ramirez said, ''but for it to turn out better than it ever was.''

HEADLINE: What If a Sales Tax Were the Only Tax?

BYLINE: By DANIEL ALTMAN

 BODY:
REPRESENTATIVE JOHN LINDER, Republican of Georgia, is a man on a mission. He wants to replace the current tax system -- or at least personal income and payroll taxes -- with a national sales tax. When he brought this idea to the floor of the House of Representatives a couple of weeks ago, Democrats chided it as a pipe dream. 
 But in August, President Bush called it ''the kind of interesting idea that we ought to explore seriously.'' From a taxpayer's perspective, it may indeed sound like a great idea: no more long instruction booklet to read, no more endless hours calculating the figures for every box on the form; you just pay at the cash register. Yet when it comes to designing such a new system, it's not quite as simple as it sounds. 
 Begin by assuming that the government needs just as much tax revenue, regardless of the system in place. Last year, the Internal Revenue Service collected about $1.7 trillion worth of individual income and payroll taxes. 
 Some of that money was returned as refunds. So, say that the government depended on those taxes to raise $1.5 trillion.
 If every bit of spending in the economy were taxed -- in other words, every one of the 12.2 trillion dollars paid by American consumers, businesses and the government for domestically produced goods and services -- the rate would have to be about 12 percent. But hold on a second. Would the government really want to tax everything? Probably not. 
 For starters, having the government pay the tax on its own purchases wouldn't actually raise any money. Take out the government's spending, and the rate would have to rise to 15 percent.
 In most states with sales taxes, food and clothing are exempt. The reason is to protect the poor. If a national sales tax lacked that exemption, poor people who pay no income tax (many actually receive a credit) would see their tax burdens grow substantially. In addition, the tax would be regressive. Because low-earning people spend a bigger share of their income than high-earning people, the low earners' taxes would be relatively higher.
 So, say Congress made food and clothing exempt. That would carve an additional $1.4 trillion out of the tax base, and the rate would have to rise to 18 percent. Remember that food and clothing just became exempt for everyone, poor or not.
 To take some of that money back, the government could try to give the exemption only to low-earners. But how would they be identified? Would they have to file -- gasp! -- a tax return reporting the previous year's income? Would the government distribute ''I'm a low-earner'' identity cards, to be shown sheepishly to cashiers? And how would the government prevent card holders from buying things for other people?
 Putting those little problems aside, there are two other issues from the current tax system: housing and medical care.
 At the moment, homeowners can deduct interest they pay on their mortgages from their income taxes. Without an income tax, this subsidy, long seen as part of what made the American dream come true, would disappear. Bringing it back, perhaps through direct grants, would require raising the national sales tax rate to 21 percent.
 In addition, the current tax system subsidizes medical spending by allowing businesses to buy insurance for their employees out of pretax dollars. Many medical expenses paid out of pocket are also deductible from personal income tax. Would we want to eliminate these subsidies? Quite a few health economists would say yes, because it would discourage people from demanding care they didn't need. To keep the subsidies, the sales tax rate might have to climb to 25 percent.
 THERE'S still one thing to account for, though: How would the new tax system affect behavior? Slapping a 25 percent tax on all the remaining purchases in the economy, by consumers and companies alike, might well affect spending. When the sales tax burden rises, prices at the checkout counter climb, but typically not by the complete amount of the tax; buyers and sellers share the burden. 
 For example, a 25 percent tax might lead to prices that are about 15 percent higher. That means a product that sold for $100 would sell for $115, including the tax. The flip side, of course, is that businesses would receive less revenue. Instead of getting $100 for that sale, a business would collect $115 minus 25 percent, or $86. Yet its costs would be the same, and it would still be paying the same corporate income tax.
 That business might react by recognizing that its employees had just received a big increase in their take-home pay, from the abolition of the income tax. The business could actually cut salaries and still leave its employees with part of that raise from Uncle Sam. In fact, doing so might be the only way to make ends meet.
 High-wage workers might find that any increase in the take-home price of goods and services would still be offset by their bigger take-home pay. But low-earners, who paid no income tax to start with, would find their budgets squeezed. So spending might actually fall, necessitating an even higher tax rate to support the federal government.
 The national sales tax might have the upper hand in one area, however.
 As part of its drive to create an ''ownership society,'' the White House is chipping away at taxes on financial income and wealth. The estate tax is scheduled to vanish, taxes on dividends and capital gains have fallen, corporate income tax loopholes have grown, and proposals for enormous tax-free saving accounts would allow the sheltering of most portfolios. 
 All of these efforts point to a system that taxes only labor income like wages and salaries. Under this system, high-earning people might be able to shift their income into primarily nontaxed sources -- for example, by taking their pay only in stocks, bonds and derivatives like options. With a national sales tax, at least, the top earners in the nation would have a much harder time avoiding taxes altogether.

HEADLINE: We've Seen the Enemy and They Are ... Who, Exactly?

BYLINE: By EDWARD WONG

DATELINE: BAGHDAD 

 BODY:
TO hear the American commanders in Iraq tell it, William Butler Yeats could well be the poet laureate of Iraq's insurgency. If the guerrillas were to win this war with their suicide car bombs and televised beheadings, what would come next? Nothing, the commanders say, but a widening gyre, and things falling apart, and, finally, mere anarchy being loosed in the cradle of civilization.
 ''This is a negative insurgency,'' Brig. Gen. Erwin Lessel, deputy director of operations for the multinational forces, said in an interview inside the fortified American headquarters here, near where two powerful bombs killed five people on Thursday and left the Americans bracing for more mayhem at the start of the holy month of Ramadan. ''Unlike a classical insurgency, these groups don't offer anything.''
 ''They've got differing goals, competing ideologies,'' he continued, ''and don't offer anything positive for the government.'' 
 The general's assertion raised a salient point about the guerrillas, particularly those in Sunni Muslim groups: A year and a half after Baghdad fell, the insurgency has yet to develop a full-fledged political wing, or a coherent political program. Classic insurgencies often have a division of labor between military and political arms, with the latter defining the goals of the struggle and pursuing them through opposition politics. The Vietcong and the Irish Republican Army, for example, had tactical commanders fighting on the battlefield while politicians hammered away at the bargaining table.
 But to think that the Sunni resistance's end goal is to spread chaos, or to assume that its lack of any apparent political machinery is a weakness that can be exploited, is to underestimate the fighters, say scholars of insurgencies who have been to Iraq.
 Yes, there are dozens of Sunni groups in the war, from Islamist cells of foreign fighters to more secular bands of former Iraqi Army officers, and they have disparate and even competing ideologies, said Bruce D. Hoffman, an insurgency analyst at the RAND Corporation. But, he added, they are united in wanting to drive America out of Iraq, and that is more than enough of a program to galvanize many Sunnis for now. 
 The universal political rule applies: The simpler the message, the more mass appeal it can gain, as the media-savvy insurgents here no doubt recognize. Presenting more sophisticated political platforms, such as ones that might lay out alternative systems of governance, could drive supporters away or reveal the discord among the groups. Within the insurgency, at least until now, hard-line clerics and secular former Baathists have no doubt maintained their marriage of convenience by focusing on the tactical goal that unites them, rather than on their competing ideologies, even as accused collaborators are threatened or executed. 
 ''You don't really need a comprehensive political program if you have a message that resonates,'' Mr. Hoffman said. ''They're not going to play around with what works.''
 A senior official in the Muslim Scholars Association, a group of Sunni clerics that has close ties to insurgent leaders, acknowledged that the goals of the cells are ''sometimes even antithetical to each other.'' 
 ''But they all have one goal, and that is to kick the Americans out of Iraq, and I don't think they'll be flexible in this goal,'' the official, Muhammad Bashar al-Fadhi, said. 
 The fact that the groups are not operating under a unified leadership with a well-developed political wing can be an advantage. The disparate nature of the insurgency has forced the Americans and the interim Iraqi government, led by Prime Minister Ayad Allawi, to try to pacify the groups one by one, an approach that leaves any deal with one group subject to being undermined by others. This problem cropped up in recent negotiations over the insurgent stronghold of Falluja: peace offers made by Dr. Allawi to the city's tribal sheiks have had no appeal for jihadists like Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, a militant from Jordan whose tactics include taping the beheadings of foreign hostages. 
 ''No one can sort out the exact motivation and ideology, or even how many groups claiming to exist are real,'' said Anthony H. Cordesman, a Middle East analyst at the Center for Strategic and International Studies. ''This makes it extremely difficult to attack the insurgents, except by one group, and center of activity, at a time.''
 The history of insurgencies shows, of course, that even a disparate rebellion can eventually unify itself and define its goals, although holding the coalition together is another matter entirely. In the recent civil war in the Congo, for example, it took years for the two major rebels groups to form political wings, which then negotiated with the standing government to enter into joint rule. Now, however, power struggles among the various factions are threatening to unravel the partnership once and for all.
 In Iraq, Mr. Hoffman says, the current American effort to hold elections in January could put pressure on the Sunni groups to lay out political programs. Now that the Sunni insurgents have struck a populist chord in central Iraq, Mr. Hoffman says, it is likely that ''political activities will increase by emerging parties that would likely be insurgent front groups.''
 ''The stakes will be too high for any party to miss out,'' Mr. Hoffman said, ''and political subversion combined with armed action is a perennial dimension of insurgency.'' 
 The Americans and the Allawi government say they hope to draw insurgent groups into the political process in order to pacify them. But, as Mr. Hoffman implied, this tactic can have its own dangers. In Algeria in 1991, for example, the fundamentalist rebels of the Islamic Salvation Front were allowed to compete in general elections, and unexpectedly won the first round. The French-backed government's response was to cancel the election results, plunging the country into a new round of civil war.
 In the weeks ahead, the Sunni insurgent groups here will no doubt watch closely the careful dance unfolding between the American military and the Allawi government on one side, and the firebrand Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr on the other. Mr. Sadr, too, has led an insurgency, but unlike the Sunni guerrillas, he has indicated for months that he wants to take part in mainstream politics. ''We have many channels; we have the armed resistance and we have the political channel,'' Ali Smesim, one of Mr. Sadr's closest aides, boasted in an interview.
 That raises some tantalizing, if risky, possibilities for American strategists who seek to replace the violence here with electoral politics. If they bargain with Mr. Sadr, and if the Sunnis see him gaining from it, the Sunni insurgents might be tempted to try to paper over their differences and form their own political front. The young Shiite cleric has already had considerable success: An arrest warrant issued against him is all but forgotten, and Iraqi and American officials have agreed not to prosecute his followers on the condition that he disarm his thousands-strong militia and channel his aggression into mainstream politics. The same officials have their doubts about how seriously he is disarming now, especially given his history of reneging on such promises, but the plan is proceeding anyway.
 In other words, just by forcing the authorities to compromise with him, Mr. Sadr has shown that an insurgent with both a private army and a populist political machine can, at this fragile moment, call at least some of the shots. This is likely the message the Sunni guerrillas are taking away right now, though it is probably not quite the lesson the Americans wanted them to learn about what entering politics can bring them.

HEADLINE: Addressing the Vote

BYLINE: By Randy Cohen

 BODY:
I've lived in New York City for seven years, paying city and state taxes and doing my time in the jury box, but I am still a legal resident of Florida as far as the Board of Elections knows. (I have a semivalid address, my parents' house.) May I ethically vote absentee there, a swing state, where it would really count, rather than here, a state almost certain to go Democratic? Patrick Parrish, New York
Are any words more evocative of the high ideals of democracy than ''semivalid address''? 
 It is exasperating indeed that the winner-take-all system of awarding electoral votes can make a vote cast in one state enormously more significant than one cast in another, but that is insufficient reason to play fast and loose with election law. There is real social good in honest elections. You ought not so casually contemplate undermining that.
 To establish legal residency in Florida, a person must declare that it is his or her ''principal home, and that he or she intends to continue it permanently as such.'' Intent is slippery. People change their minds about where they want to live, and no harm done. And college students, for example, may simply be unsure and should not be disenfranchised for it. But your situation is clear: you are a New Yorker; so unless you plan to migrate South -- which might please your candidate but alarm your parents -- you're out of luck. 
 In lieu of my making a caustic remark about Florida's idiosyncratic method of tallying (or not tallying) certain votes, insert your own joke here.
 My mother wants to hire someone to clean house and handle the laundry. To assure this person's integrity, she plans to leave loose money around as ''bait'' during the housecleaner's first few days of work. Here in Brazil, those stray bills can constitute a significant percentage of a housecleaner's wages. My mother sees this ''trap'' as a perfectly ethical precaution. Do you? Daniel Hutchins, Juiz de Fora, Brazil
 Your use of ''trap'' implies one distasteful feature of your mother's scheme: it tiptoes toward entrapment, if not legally, then certainly ethically. The target is minding her own business, only to be lured into wrongdoing. While others working in your mother's house might be in a position to steal, they are unlikely to come upon piles of cash -- so impersonal, so fungible, so pocket-size. Theft is clearly wrong, but there is a well-known injunction not to put temptation in someone's path. (''Tempt not a desperate man,'' says Romeo to Paris.) That's why I don't wear a sport coat made of hundred-dollar bills. (That and because I look so sickly in green.)
 People are not crudely divisible into honest and dishonest; different circumstances elicit different behaviors in us all. (Millions of otherwise law-abiding citizens have illegally downloaded music.) As a prudent employer, your mother should not strew cash around the house; as a sensitive human being, she should be mindful of the economic gulf between her and her housekeeper. We do not wave food in the faces of the hungry.
 This sort of integrity testing might be justifiable were there probable cause of serious wrongdoing and no other way to address it -- for example, in a police precinct plagued by bribe-taking. But it should be a last resort, not a routine part of the job application.
 Your mother would do better to check references and hire someone of demonstrated honesty. In any case, she doesn't keep the crown jewels in her bathroom; she will have time to act if her baubles begin vanishing.
